{{Notice| [https://docs.legis.wisconsin.gov/misc/lfb/informational_papers/january_2021/0003_individual_income_tax_provisions_in_the_states_informational_paper_3.pdf Individual Income Tax Provisions in the States], from the [https://docs.legis.wisconsin.gov/misc/lfb/informational_papers Wisconsin Legislative Fiscal Bureau], contains a comprehensive summary of taxation categories in all states with an income tax, as of January 2021. }} '''{{PAGENAME}}''' do not always work the same way as Federal taxes. Understanding the differences specific to your state may be useful in making investment plans, and people giving advice to investors in other states need to know other state-specific issues. This page is a summary of the major differences between state and federal taxes, with links to each state's tax page. If your state is not listed on this page and you know something about the state tax, please add it.
==All states== In most states with an income tax, the tax works essentially the same as the Federal tax. You compute your total income, subtract itemized deductions or a standard deduction. subtract personal exemptions (or, in some states, take a dollar credit for personal exemptions), and pay a tax based on the tax rate; the only difference is that certain items are taxed differently. States in which the tax works in a very different way (for example, no standard deduction and only limited itemized deductions, or only some types of income taxed) will be indicated below.
''States with no income tax'': Alaska, Florida, Nevada, New Hampshire,<ref name="Tax Foundation" /><ref name="StatesNoIncomeTax" /><ref name="NewHampshireTax">{{cite web| url=https://www.revenue.nh.gov/taxes-glance/interest-dividends-tax/| title=Interest and Dividends Tax| publisher=New Hampshire Department of Revenue Administration| accessdate=August 20, 2024}}</ref> South Dakota, Tennessee, Texas, Washington, and Wyoming.<ref name="Tax Foundation">{{cite web| url=https://taxfoundation.org/data/all/state/state-income-tax-rates-2024/| title=State Individual Income Tax Rates 2024| publisher=Tax Foundation| accessdate=August 20, 2024}}</ref><ref name="StatesNoIncomeTax">{{cite web| url=https://turbotax.intuit.com/tax-tips/fun-facts/9-states-with-no-income-tax/amp/c9RZgthD3| title=9 States with no Income Tax| publisher=Intuit, Inc| accessdate=August 20, 2024}}</ref>
Washington has no income tax but does have a tax on capital gains for very high earners.<ref name="WashingtonCapGains">{{cite web| url=https://dor.wa.gov/taxes-rates/other-taxes/capital-gains-tax| title=Washington Capital Gains| publisher=Washington State Department of Revenue| accessdate=August 20, 2024}}</ref>
''States with flat rates'': Arizona, Colorado, Georgia, Idaho, Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, Massachusetts, Michigan, Mississippi, North Carolina, Pennsylvania, and Utah.<ref name="Tax Foundation" /><ref name="StateFlatTaxes">{{cite web| url=https://taxfoundation.org/blog/flat-tax-state-income-tax-reform/| title=The State Flat Tax Revolution: Where Things Stand Today| publisher=Tax Foundation| date=February 15, 2024| accessdate=August 20, 2024}}</ref> Iowa has implemented a flat tax effective 2025.<ref name="IowaTax">{{cite web|date=May 1, 2024|title=Gov. Kim Reynolds signs law lowering individual income tax rate to 3.8% in 2025|url=https://iowacapitaldispatch.com/2024/05/01/gov-kim-reynolds-signs-law-lowering-individual-income-tax-rate-to-3-8-in-2025/|accessdate=August 20, 2024|publisher=Iowa Capital Dispatch}}</ref> Louisiana has a single rate income tax effective 1/1/2025.<ref name="LouisianaTax">{{cite web|title=2025 State Tax Changes|url=https://taxfoundation.org/research/all/state/2025-state-tax-changes/#:~:text=Thirty%2Dnine%20states%20will%20begin,new%20first%2Dyear%20expensing%20provisions.|publisher=Tax Foundation}}</ref>
Massachusetts has added a surtax to very high incomes on top of their otherwise flat tax.<ref name="MassSurtax">{{cite web| url=https://www.mass.gov/news/4-surtax-on-taxable-income-over-1000000-the-basics#:~:text=What%20is%20the%204%25%20surtax,for%20the%20tax%20year%202023.| title=4% Surtax on Taxable Income Over $1,000,000: The Basics| publisher=Massachusetts Department of Revenue| date=January 26, 2024| accessdate=August 20, 2024}}</ref>
===Interest and dividends=== States cannot tax the Federal Government; therefore, interest on Government obligations, such as [[Treasury bonds]] and [[TIPS]] (but not [[GNMA]]s), is exempt from state tax. On the other hand, most states do tax obligations of other states, so income from [[municipal bonds]] from other states is exempt from Federal tax but subject to state tax. In most states, if a fund contains a mixture of taxable and tax-exempt income (for example, a bond fund holding both Treasury and corporate bonds), the tax-exempt income is not taxed by the state; some states require a minimum percentage of the fund to be tax-exempt to get any tax benefit.
===Deductions=== Most states do not allow an itemized deduction for state and local taxes, although some allow the deduction for taxes paid to other states or out-of-state localities, some allow deduction for their own state, and some do allows a deduction for taxes paid to all states. A few states allow a deduction for Federal taxes, which significantly reduces the effective tax rate.
===Multiple state tax issues=== States that impose a personal income tax generally require that tax be paid on all income earned in that state, as well as all income earned by residents of the state. This may result in the need to pay taxes to multiple states, but there are provisions to reduce both the tax and the paperwork burden.
====Reciprocity with neighboring states==== For employees who work in one state but live in another, a tax return must be filed in both states. To alleviate this double filing burden, many neighboring states have agreements not to tax salaries earned by each other's residents. This makes taxes easier to handle for commuters, as most commuters have no income earned in the other state except for salaries.
Generally, under these agreements, one state will not tax a resident of the other state on compensation that is subject to employer withholding. These agreements apply to most types of W-2 compensation earned while a resident of the reciprocal compensation agreement state.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.revenue.pa.gov/TaxTypes/PIT/Pages/Determining-Residency.aspx#:~:text=What%20are%20reciprocal%20tax%20agreements,compensation%20subject%20to%20employer%20withholding| title=Determining Residency for PA Personal Income Tax Purposes| publisher=Pennsylvania Department of Revenue| accessdate=August 20, 2024}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.nj.gov/treasury/taxation/njit25.shtml| title=NJ Income Tax - PA/NJ Reciprocal Income Tax Agreement| publisher=NJ Treasury| accessdate=August 20, 2024}}</ref> For convenience, an employer ''may'' withhold taxes at the employee's resident state tax rate.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://revenue-pa.custhelp.com/app/answers/detail/a_id/270/related/1/session/L2F2LzQvdGltZS8xMjk2NDIxMTM5L3NpZC9LVzZPaG9saw%3D%3D| title=Is there any thing I can do if my reciprocal state employer refuses to withhold PA Personal Income Tax?| quote=It is not mandatory for an employer to withhold out of state taxes for non-residents.| date=November 14, 2022| accessdate=August 20, 2024}}</ref>
For example, a Pennsylvania resident working in New Jersey (Pennsylvania has reciprocal agreements with New Jersey and five other states) could have taxes withheld for Pennsylvania at the Pennsylvania rate. Only a Pennsylvania state tax form is needed; no additional forms are to be filed for New Jersey unless the resident owes New Jersey tax for some other reason (for example, property sold in New Jersey).
====Credit for taxes paid to another state==== If you pay taxes to two states on the same income (because both consider you to be a resident, or because you are a resident of one but earned income in the other), the states allow a credit analogous to the [[foreign tax credit]]. The credit is usually the lesser of the amount you paid to the other state, or a prorated share of the tax you paid to the state where you took the credit.
For example, if you are a resident of State X with income of $100,000, of which $20,000 was taxable in State Y, and you paid $6,000 in tax to State X, then you are entitled to a $1,200 credit if you paid $1,200 or more to State Y, and otherwise only a credit of the amount you paid to State Y.
====Nonresidents and part-year residents==== Nonresident tax is normally computed on a prorated basis. If you are a nonresident of state Y and have total income of $100,000, of which $20,000 is taxable in State Y, then you compute the State Y tax on the full $100,000, and 20% of the total is your State Y tax.
Some states tax part-year residents the same as non-residents, prorating full-year income. Other states do not prorate. In the example above, if you moved to State Y during the year and earned a total of $100,000, of which $20,000 was earned while you were a resident, and State Y does not prorate, then you would owe the tax on $20,000 rather than 20% of the tax on $100,000. If the tax in State Y is flat, this would not matter, but if the tax is progressive, you would owe much less tax because of the lack of proration.
===Withholding=== If you do not fill out a state withholding form, most states will withhold income tax using the same number of allowances as on the Federal [https://www.irs.gov/forms-pubs/about-form-w-4 W-4 form]. This is often incorrect, either because your itemized deductions and credits are different (since state taxes are not deductible on the state form, and most Federal tax credits do not apply to the states) or because the amount a state assigns to an allowance is different (if a state has a $1,000 personal exemption, then $20,000 of extra itemized deductions is 20 state allowances). Check your state withholding when you file your federal W-4 to avoid getting a large refund or a penalty.
===Use tax=== All states with sales taxes also impose a use tax on goods purchased out of state for use in the state by state residents; sales tax paid to another state can be taken as a credit against that tax. This tax is not part of the income tax, but in many states, there is a line on the income tax form for use tax payments to encourage compliance, and some states provide a formula for estimating the tax due if the taxpayer does not keep records.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.house.mn.gov/hrd/pubs/usetax.pdf| title=Use Tax Collection on Income Tax Returns in Other States| publisher=Research Department, Minnesota House of Representatives| date=April 2015| accessdate=August 20, 2024}}</ref>
==Specific states== This section is not intended to be a comprehensive guide to the details of state taxes, just a summary of the most important issues. Go to the state web site or check with a tax advisor for details.
===Specific issues for investors=== This section is a summary of investment strategies which may be affected by state tax issues. See the following section for a more complete summary.
*'''Any state with no income tax''' — Minor preference for Roth over traditional accounts (you may pay tax on traditional account withdrawals if you retire in another state). More attractive to pay down a mortgage (interest not deductible). More attractive to invest in corporate bonds rather than Treasury bonds in a taxable account.
*[https://www.revenue.alabama.gov/tax-types/individual-income-tax/ Alabama] — The first $6,000 per year of 401k or IRA withdrawals is exempt from state income tax for taxpayers 65 and older.
*[https://www.azdor.gov/ Arizona] — Foreign investments in a taxable account are more attractive, because of a foreign tax credit against state as well as federal tax.
*[https://www.dfa.arkansas.gov/income-tax/individual-income-tax Arkansas] — First $6,000 of retirement plan distributions (per spouse if married) are tax exempt, which may factor into traditional vs Roth decisions.
*[https://www.ftb.ca.gov/index.shtml California] — Prefer Treasury bonds in a Health Savings Account. Other investments are taxed.
*[https://tax.colorado.gov Colorado] — A slight preference for traditional contributions during working years; some retirement account withdrawals are excludable from income starting at age 55. For the same reason, small Roth conversions after age 55 may be beneficial.
*[https://revenue.delaware.gov/ Delaware] — A minor advantage for foreign investments in a taxable account, because foreign tax is deductible.
*[https://dor.georgia.gov Georgia] — All except high-income taxpayers should prefer traditional to Roth accounts. Contributions are deductible, and the huge exclusion means that only high-income taxpayers will owe any Georgia tax on the income after age 65. Tax efficiency for middle-income taxpayers while they are still working is more important — capital gains are taxed by Georgia while they are working, but are unlikely to be taxed after 65.
*[https://tax.illinois.gov/questionsandanswers/answer.99.html Illinois] — Illinois does not tax retirement account distributions, which can factor into traditional vs Roth decisions.
*[https://www.in.gov/dor/ Indiana] — It is more attractive to pay down a mortgage (interest not deductible).
*[https://revenue.iowa.gov/taxes/tax-guidance/individual-income-tax/retirement-income-tax-guidance Iowa] — Iowa does not tax retirement account distributions for retirees over 55 effective 2023, which can factor into traditional vs Roth decisions.
*[https://revenue.ky.gov/Individual/Individual-Income-Tax/Pages/default.aspx Kentucky] — Kentucky has a significant income exclusions for pensions and retirement account distributions, which favors traditional contributions over Roth.
*[https://revenue.louisiana.gov/individualincometax Louisiana] — Louisiana has a small retirement income distribution exemption that may be a factor in traditional vs Roth decisions.
*[https://www.marylandtaxes.gov/ Maryland] — Prefer not to roll an entire retirement plan into an IRA. Some pension income is excluded from tax but this is lost in an IRA.
*[https://www.mass.gov/dor Massachusetts] — Use banks in Massachusetts in preference to other banks (some Massachusetts interest is not taxed). Prefer Roth to traditional IRA even if traditional would be federally deductible, because there is no state deduction. It is more attractive to pay down a mortgage, since interest is not deductible.
*[https://www.michigan.gov/taxes Michigan] — It is more attractive to pay down a mortgage, since interest not deductible. For taxpayers without pensions, prefer traditional to Roth accounts, as a large amount of retirement income is not taxed.
*[https://www.dor.ms.gov/individual/individual-income-tax-faqs Mississippi] — Retirement income, including qualified distributions from retirement accounts is not taxed in Mississippi, which is a consideration in traditional vs Roth decisions.
*[https://www.revenue.nh.gov/taxes-glance/interest-dividends-tax New Hampshire] — Interest and dividend tax phase out after 2024.
*[https://www.state.nj.us/treasury/taxation/ New Jersey] — High-income investors, or investors who might retire in another state, should prefer Roth to traditional accounts except for 401(k)s. Traditional IRA, 403(b), 457, Thrift Savings Plans are not deductible; moderate-income New Jersey investors may be able to exclude the entire income in retirement. All except high-income investors should prefer traditional to Roth 401(k) (deductible, and may not be taxed in retirement). Prefer Treasury bonds in a traditional IRA (not taxed; it is not clear from the instructions whether this applies to other traditional accounts). It is more attractive to pay down a mortgage, because interest is not deductible. Prefer Treasury bonds in a Health Savings Account (other investments are taxed).
*[https://www.tax.ny.gov/pit/ New York] — Prefer to have at least some traditional rather than Roth accounts. Moderate-income taxpayers should prefer traditional to Roth for most retirement income ($20,000 per person excluded).
*[https://www.ncdor.gov/taxes-forms/individual-income-tax/ North Carolina] - [https://www.ncdor.gov/taxes-forms/tax-rate-schedules Flat tax rate] scheduled to drop and then plateau by tax year 2026. Tax benefits for [https://www.ncdor.gov/taxes-forms/individual-income-tax/military-retirement/ military retirees]. The [https://www.ncdor.gov/bailey-decision-concerning-federal-state-and-local-retirement-benefits Bailey court decision] limits how much the state can tax certain retirees, including federal pensioners with 5 or more years of creditable service as of August 12, 1989.
*[https://www.oregon.gov/dor/programs/individuals/pages/pit.aspx/ Oregon] — Oregon has one of the highest income tax rates in the nation, up to 9.9% over $125,000. There may be additional local income taxes. Tax deferral strategies such as traditional 401ks, IRAs, HSAs and deferred compensation plans take on added importance. Oregon also has an inheritance tax of 10%-16% over $1,000,000, making estate planning a necessity for even comparatively more modest estates. See [https://avieradvisors.com/smart-tax-strategies-for-oregon-residents/ Smart Tax Strategies], [https://smartasset.com/estate-planning/how-to-avoid-oregon-estate-tax/ Oregon Estate Tax Strategies], and [https://www.forbes.com/advisor/income-tax-calculator/oregon/#:~:text=If%20your%20income%20is%20over,of%20the%20excess%20over%20%2410%2C200./ Oregon Tax Calculator].
*[https://www.revenue.pa.gov/TaxTypes/PIT/Pages/default.aspx Pennsylvania] — Minor preference for Roth over traditional accounts. Neither is deductible or taxable in Pennsylvania, but you may pay tax on traditional account withdrawals if you retire in another state. It is more attractive to pay down a mortgage, because interest is not deductible.
*[https://tax.ri.gov/tax-sections/personal-income-tax Rhode Island] — Those with low or moderate incomes may prefer traditional vs Roth contributions to employer retirement plans (not including IRAs) as some withdrawals are tax exempt.
*[https://dor.sc.gov/tax/individual-income South Carolina] — modest tax deduction for retirement plan distributions, potentially affecting traditional vs Roth decisions.
*[https://tax.vermont.gov/individuals/personal-income-tax Vermont] — Vermont offers a modest retirement account distributions exemption, subject to AGI constraints, that should be considered in traditional vs Roth decisions.
*[https://www.tax.virginia.gov/ Virginia] — No special issues.
*[https://dor.wa.gov/taxes-rates/other-taxes/capital-gains-tax Washington] — while Washington has no income tax there is currently an excise capital gains tax for very high amounts of capital gains ($262,000 in 2023).
===Tax details===
====Alabama==== [https://www.revenue.alabama.gov/tax-types/individual-income-tax/ Alabama] — Alabama has three income tax brackets, but the brackets are low and most taxpayers reach the top bracket. Capital losses are deducted against income in the year realized, with no limitation and thus no need for carryover.
The first $6,000 of 401k or IRA withdrawals are tax exempt for those 65 years and older.
Social Security and income from defined-benefit pension plans are not taxed.
$5,000 of contributions to the Alabama 529 Plan is subtracted from income per taxpayer and $10,000 for married filing jointly if both spouses contribute.
Federal tax is deducted from taxable income in addition to the standard or itemized deductions.
Taxpayers below certain income limits with health insurance through small employers may deduct 100% of their health insurance premiums.
All federal taxes other than income tax are deductible as itemized deductions; this includes Social Security, Medicare, self-employment tax, and gift tax if paid by the giver. Tax paid to a city or county is deductible from state tax (most states do not allow this).
Qualified long-term care premiums are fully deductible, and other medical expenses in excess of 4% of adjusted gross income are deductible (compared to 7.5% for federal tax).
Part-year resident taxes are not prorated, but this has little effect because the tax rate is almost flat.
See also: [https://www.kiplinger.com/state-by-state-guide-taxes/alabama Alabama State Tax Guide], from Kiplinger.
====Alaska==== [https://www.commerce.alaska.gov/web/dcra/officeofthestateassessor/alaskataxfacts.aspx Alaska] — Alaska has no personal state income tax.
====Arizona==== [https://www.azdor.gov/ Arizona] — Arizona has a flat state income tax rate. Social Security is not taxed. Capital gains are taxed at the same rate as ordinary income at the flat tax rate. Contributions to certain types of Arizona charities may be taken as a credit rather than a deduction, up to a limit; the remainder may be taken as a deduction. 31% of charitable contributions may be deducted as an increased standard deduction even if you itemize.
Credit for taxes paid to a foreign country, computed as for credit to taxes paid to another state. Part-year resident taxes are not prorated. Arizona 529 plan participants are allowed to deduct from income $2000 per beneficiary for single taxpayers and $4000 per beneficiary for married taxpayers.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://az529.gov/what-is-a-529-plan/az-tax-incentives/#:~:text=The%20State%20of%20Arizona%20provides,to%20any%20state's%20529%20plan.| title=AZ Tax Advantages - Arizona's Education Savings Plan| publisher=Office of the Arizona State Treasurer| accessdate=August 22, 2024}}</ref>
====Arkansas==== [https://www.dfa.arkansas.gov/income-tax/individual-income-tax Arkansas] — Arkansas has a graduated state income tax. Social Security is not taxed. The first $6000 of retirement income, or $12,000 if both spouses have applicable income each [https://support.taxslayer.com/hc/en-us/articles/360028254491-Is-my-retirement-income-taxable-to-Arkansas#:~:text=Arkansas%20allows%20you%20take%20a,return%20for%20your%20retirement%20income. including from retirement accounts] is tax exempt for those over 59.5 years old. 50% of net long term capital gains and 100% of short term capital gains are taxed as income. [https://www.dfa.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/incomeTaxOffice/2022_AR1000D_CapitalGains.pdf]. Arkansas offers tax deductions for those who contribute to Arkansas 529, and also a lesser deduction to those who contribute to a 529 outside of Arkansas. [https://www.kiplinger.com/state-by-state-guide-taxes/arkansas][https://portal.arkansas.gov/service/arkansas-brighter-future-529-plan/#:~:text=Arkansas%20taxpayers%20are%20eligible%20to,Brighter%20Future%20529%20Plan%20account.][https://brighterfuturedirect529.com/home/help-center.html#:~:text=The%20State%20of%20Arkansas%20offers,Arkansas%20Brighter%20Future%20529%20Plan.]
====California==== [https://www.ftb.ca.gov/index.shtml California] — California has a graduated state income tax and is one of the highest in the nation. There is also a state employee payroll tax. In 2024 the state employee payroll tax cap was eliminated. Health Savings Accounts are not recognized: employer contributions are taxed as income and employee contributions are not deductible, but then distributions not used for qualified medical expenses, and included in federal income, are not taxed.
All interest from tax-exempt mutual funds is taxed unless at least 50% of the assets are in bonds not taxed by California. Social Security is not taxed. All other retirement is taxable. There is an additional tax on early withdrawals of retirement accounts. Unemployment compensation is not taxed.
You cannot deduct Private Mortgage Insurance, estate tax paid on income in respect of a decedent, or tax paid on generation skipping transfers. You cannot deduct losing California lottery tickets as gambling losses.
====Colorado==== [https://tax.colorado.gov Colorado] — Colorado has a flat state income tax. Up to $20,000 (if age 55-64) or $24,000 (if age 65+) of "pension and annuity income" (which includes IRA and employer retirement plan withdrawals, annuity income, and Social Security benefits) may be excluded from income. These amounts are per-spouse for married couples filing jointly.
The Colorado Tuition Program Deduction (529 Deduction) allows individuals, estates, and trusts to deduct an amount equivalent to their total contributions to a 529 account from their taxable income. The deduction is capped at $20,000 and $30,000 per taxpayer, per beneficiary for single and joint filers, respectively.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://leg.colorado.gov/sites/default/files/te6_colorado_tuition_program_529_deduction.pdf| title=Colorado Tuition Program Deduction| publisher=Colorado.gov| accessdate=August 22, 2024}}</ref>
====Connecticut==== [https://portal.ct.gov/drs/individuals/individual-income-tax Connecticut] — Connecticut has a graduated state income tax. Social security is not taxable for AGI less than $75k if single or $100k if MFJ or HOH. Annuities and pensions are tax exempt for AGIs of $75k for singles and HOH and $100k for MFJ. For 2024, 50% of income from IRA distributions is tax-exempt for filers who meet the same income guidelines set for pension and annuity income (less than $100,000 for joint filers and less than $75,000 for all other filers). Eligible taxpayers can exempt 75% of IRA distribution income in 2025 and 100% in 2026. [https://www.kiplinger.com/state-by-state-guide-taxes/connecticut#:~:text=Connecticut%20has%20a%20graduated%20state,adjusted%20gross%20income)%20below%20%2475%2C000.] Connecticut families can take an income tax deduction (up to $5,000 for single filers, $10,000 for joint filers) on contributions to CHET 529 accounts. [https://portal.ct.gov/ott/financial-wellness/chet/connecticut-higher-education-trust---chet]
====Delaware==== [https://revenue.delaware.gov/ Delaware] — Delaware has a graduated state income tax. There may also be local income taxes. Social Security is not taxable. Taxpayers under 60 may deduct up to $2,000 of pension income; an early distribution from an IRA or Pension fund due to emergency reasons or a separation from employment does not qualify. Each taxpayer may receive one exclusion; a husband and wife who each receive pensions are entitled to one exclusion each. Taxpayers 60 and over may deduct up to $12,500 of eligible retirement income which includes: dividends, capital gains, interest, net rental income from real property and qualified retirement plans (IRC Sec. 4974).
Taxes paid to other states are deductible if a credit was not claimed (for example, a tax paid for a previous year in which you were not a Delaware resident); taxes paid to counties or cities are deductible because no credit is allowed. Foreign income tax is deductible even if a federal credit was taken. 50% of federal child care credit is allowed as a non-refundable state credit. A state earned income tax credit is allowed for either 20% of federal earned income tax credit as a non-refundable credit, or 4.5% of federal earned income tax credit as a refundable credit.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://revenuefiles.delaware.gov/2023/PIT-RES_TY23_2023-01_Instructions.pdf| title=DELAWARE Individual Income Tax Return - Instructions| publisher=Delaware.gov| accessdate=August 22, 2024}}</ref>
Withdrawals from retirement plans (including IRAs) for higher education expenses are exempt from state tax.
DE529 plan account owners are eligible to claim a DE529 state income tax deduction for contributions to the DE529 plan account made in the applicable tax year. Single persons may claim up to a $1,000 deduction, and married persons filing jointly may claim up to a $2,000 state income tax deduction.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.fidelity.com/529-plans/delaware| title=The DE529 Education Savings Plan| publisher=Fidelity| accessdate=August 22, 2024}}</ref>
====Florida==== [https://floridarevenue.com/taxes/taxesfees/Pages/tax_interest_rates.aspx Florida] — Florida has no personal income tax.
====Georgia==== [https://dor.georgia.gov/ Georgia] — Georgia has a flat state income tax. Most older retirees will pay no tax, because of a very large "retirement income" exclusion; the retirement exclusion includes all investments, not just retirement plan, and up to $4,000 of earned income, up to $65,000 per person age 65+ or $35,000 per person age 62-64 or disabled. A married couple can claim exclusions for both. Social Security is not taxed. Georgia state tax is deductible, and refunds taxable; tax paid to other states is not deductible (but credits can be claimed as usual). 30% of the federal child and dependent care credit is allowed as a credit; there are also credits for caregivers and purchasers of single-family homes.
Non-residents who earn only salary in Georgia need not file taxes unless they earn more than 5% of their salary or $5,000 in Georgia. Contributions to Georgia 529 plan up to $4,000 per year, per beneficiary, are eligible for a Georgia state income tax deduction for those filing a single return; and $8,000 per year, per beneficiary, for those filling a joint return.
====Hawaii==== [https://tax.hawaii.gov/ Hawaii] — Hawaii has a graduated state income tax with multiple brackets. Capital gains are taxed at a flat rate. Social security and pensions are tax exempt, but retirement account distributions are taxable. Hawaii allows for various itemized deductions and also has various tax credits available. [https://www.forbes.com/advisor/income-tax-calculator/hawaii/#:~:text=What%20You%20Need%20To%20Know,doesn't%20charge%20sales%20tax.][https://www.kiplinger.com/state-by-state-guide-taxes/hawaii]
====Idaho==== [https://tax.idaho.gov/taxes/income-tax/individual-income/online-guide/ Idaho] — Idaho has a flat state income tax. Social Security benefits are exempt. [https://www.kiplinger.com/state-by-state-guide-taxes/idaho#:~:text=Idaho%20income%20taxes&text=Idaho%20has%20a%20flat%20income,not%20taxed%20by%20the%20state.] If you contribute to an IDeal 529 account, you can claim an Idaho income tax deduction for your contribution of up to $6,000 per year or $12,000 if you’re married and file a joint return. You can take the deduction even if you don’t itemize.[https://tax.idaho.gov/taxes/income-tax/individual-income/popular-credits-and-deductions/ideal-college-savings-program/]
====Illinois==== [https://tax.illinois.gov/research/taxrates/income.html Illinois] — Illinois has a flat personal income tax. Illinois does not tax social security income, pension distributions or retirement plan income, including from IRAs, 401(k) plans and government retirement plans.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://tax.illinois.gov/questionsandanswers/answer.99.html| title=Does Illinois tax my pension, social security, or retirement income?| publisher=Illinois Department of Revenue| accessdate=August 20, 2024}}</ref> Investment income is taxed at the same tax rate as earnings. Each year, you can deduct your contributions to your Bright Start 529 account up to $10,000 per individual taxpayer and $20,000 for a married couple filing jointly.
====Indiana==== [https://www.in.gov/dor/ Indiana] — Indiana has a flat state income tax. Municipal Income exempt from Federal taxes is exempt from Indiana taxes no matter which state it comes from if bond acquired before January 1, 2012. State income tax deducted from federal tax as a non-itemized deduction (on schedule C, C-EZ, E, or F) is taxable. Unemployment compensation is taxed in full. Social Security is not taxed. Pensions and retirement account income are taxed.
No general standard or itemized deductions, but limited deductions for property taxes and renters. 10% of federal earned income credit allowed as state credit. Counties can charge an income tax that is paid with the state tax; tax paid to another state can be takes as a credit against state tax, and tax paid to an out-of-state county or city can be taken as a credit against county tax. Indiana residents who sign up for the Indiana 529 Direct Savings Plan get a state income tax credit equal to 20 percent of your contributions, up to $1,500 per year.
====Iowa==== [https://revenue.iowa.gov/taxes/tax-guidance/individual-income-tax/retirement-income-tax-guidance Iowa] — Iowa does not tax social security and [https://revenue.iowa.gov/taxes/tax-guidance/individual-income-tax/retirement-income-tax-guidance does not tax retirement account distributions], pensions and other retirement income for retirees over 55 effective 2023. Iowa has 3 tax brackets for 2023 and 2024 and will have a flat tax in 2025.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.desmoinesregister.com/story/news/politics/2024/05/01/kim-reynolds-signs-iowa-law-lowering-state-income-tax-rate-3-8-ieda/73503143007/| title=Iowa Gov. Kim Reynolds signs law speeding up 3.8% flat income tax rate| publisher=Des Moines Register| date=May 1, 2024| accessdate=August 20, 2024}}</ref> If an Iowa 529 Participant (saver) is an Iowa taxpayer, they can deduct up to $5,500 in contributions per Beneficiary account from their state income taxes in 2024. This number is adjusted annually for inflation.
====Kansas==== [https://www.ksrevenue.gov/taxrates.html Kansas] — Kansas has a graduated state income tax. [https://www.ksrevenue.gov/taxrates.html]. Social Security is no longer taxable as of 2024[https://www.kiplinger.com/state-by-state-guide-taxes/kansas]. Some municipalities may have an intangibles tax on investment accounts [https://www.ksrevenue.gov/perstaxtypesint.html]. Kansas taxpayers may take an annual deduction of up to $3,000 ($6,000 for married, filing jointly) from Kansas adjusted gross income for contributions into each beneficiary's 529 account.[https://www.kansasstatetreasurer.ks.gov/learn_quest.html]
====Kentucky==== [https://revenue.ky.gov/Individual/Individual-Income-Tax/Pages/default.aspx Kentucky] — Kentucky has a flat income tax. Some jurisdictions may also have a local income tax[https://smartasset.com/taxes/kentucky-tax-calculator#:~:text=Kentucky%20has%20a%20flat%20income%20tax%20rate%20of%204.5%25%2C%20a,right%20around%20the%20U.S.%20mark.]. Social Security is not taxable. Private Pensions are partially taxable. Retirement account distributions are taxable, but there is an exclusion amount available for such retirement income ($31,110 in 2023)[https://support.taxslayer.com/hc/en-us/articles/360015904651-Is-my-retirement-income-taxable-to-Kentucky][https://www.kiplinger.com/state-by-state-guide-taxes/kentucky#:~:text=Kentucky%20income%20tax%20rate&text=Kentucky%20generally%20has%20a%20flat,income%20tax%20rate%20was%204.5%25.]. Kentucky does not offer a deduction for 529 contributions [https://thecollegeinvestor.com/529-plan-guide/kentucky/].
====Louisiana==== [https://revenue.louisiana.gov/individualincometax Louisiana] — Effective 1/1/2025 Louisiana has a single rate income tax as well as a higher $12,500 standard deduction. [https://taxfoundation.org/research/all/state/2025-state-tax-changes/#:~:text=Thirty%2Dnine%20states%20will%20begin,new%20first%2Dyear%20expensing%20provisions.] Previously it had a graduated state income tax[https://www.kiplinger.com/state-by-state-guide-taxes/louisiana#:~:text=Louisiana%20income%20tax%20rate&text=Louisiana%20has%20a%20graduated%20state,from%201.85%25%20to%204.25%25.]. Social Security is not taxable. Taxpayers age 65 and older can exclude up to $6,000 of annual retirement income from their taxable income. If filing jointly, each spouse 65 and older can exclude up to $6,000. [https://revenue.louisiana.gov/Faq/Details/1216]. Deposits to Louisiana START 529 accounts are deductible from reported Louisiana income, up to $2,400 per year, per beneficiary. Married couples filing jointly may deduct deposits up to a maximum of $4,800 per year, per beneficiary. Any unused portion may be carried forward to subsequent tax years. Some qualifying account owners can deduct twice the stated limits. [https://www.startsaving.la.gov/startfaqs.aspx][https://www.startsaving.la.gov/Common/Docs/Disclosure_Booklet_and_Participation_Agreements.pdf]
====Maine==== [https://www.maine.gov/revenue/taxes/income-estate-tax/individual-income-tax-1040me Maine] — Maine has a graduated income tax. Social Security is not taxed[https://www.kiplinger.com/state-by-state-guide-taxes/maine#:~:text=Maine%20state%20tax%3A%20Overview,than%20%246.41%20million%20are%20exempt.]. Starting 2023 Maine offers a tax deduction of up to $1000 to Maine 529 accounts. [https://www.nextgenforme.com/maine-state-tax-deduction/#:~:text=A%20new%20Maine%20law%20goes,student%20for%20Maine%20state%20taxpayers.]
====Maryland==== [https://www.marylandtaxes.gov/ Maryland] — Maryland has a graduated state income tax with multiple brackets. Social Security is not taxed, and some pension income (a moderate allowance, but reduced by taxable Social Security) is not taxed for taxpayers over 65. Single taxpayers over 65 get a $1,000 tax credit if their federal AGI is at most $100,000; married taxpayers over 65 get a $1,750 tax credit if their federal AGI is at most $150K. Up to $5,000 per year can be deducted from state tax if contributed to a Maryland First-Time Homebuyer Savings Account; withdrawals up to $50,000 for first-time home purchase are state tax-free, but withdrawals for other purposes are taxable with a 10% penalty.
Capital gains on bonds exempt from Maryland tax (Treasuries or in-state munis) are not taxed; capital gains from funds holding these bonds are taxable. 50% of federal earned income credit, plus a county credit, allowed as state credit. Itemized deductions allowed only if deductions were itemized on the federal return; standard deduction may be taken even if itemized deductions were taken on the federal return. Counties charge an income tax that is paid with the state tax; a 2015 Supreme Court ruling says that tax paid to another state can be taken as a credit against the combined total of state and county tax.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/575/542/| title=Comptroller of Treasury of Md. v. Wynne :: 575 U.S. 542 (2015)| publisher=Justia US Supreme Court Center| date=May 18, 2015| accessdate=August 20, 2024}}</ref> Part-year resident taxes are not prorated.
If you are Maryland 529 account owner or a contributor, you can subtract up to $2,500 per beneficiary from your Maryland state income for contributions in that calendar year. Contributions in excess of $2,500 per beneficiary can be carried forward and subtracted for up to the next 10 years.[https://maryland529.com/home/tax-advantages.html#:~:text=Maryland%20College%20Investment%20Plan,to%20the%20next%2010%20years.]
====Massachusetts==== [https://www.mass.gov/dor/ Massachusetts] — Earned income is taxed at a flat rate, 5.0% as of 2023. A 4% income surtax on incomes over $1,000,000+ (threshold increased each year)[https://www.kiplinger.com/state-by-state-guide-taxes/massachusetts]. Long-term capital gains from investments are taxed at 5 percent in Massachusetts, and short-term capital gains are taxed at 8.5 percent[https://states.aarp.org/massachusetts/state-taxes-guide#:~:text=Long%2Dterm%20capital%20gains%20from,are%20taxed%20at%208.5%20percent.]. There is a 12% tax rate on short-term capital gains, and long-term gains on collectibles are taxed half as short-term and half as long-term; deductions do not apply against the amount taxed at 12%. Massachusetts bank interest is exempt up to $100 ($200 for married filing jointly)[https://budget.digital.mass.gov/govbudget/fy23/tax-expenditure-budget/personal-income-tax/deductions-from-adjusted-gross-income/1-413#:~:text=Up%20to%20%24100%20(%24200,is%20deductible%20from%20gross%20income.]. Capital losses offset up to $2,000 in dividends and interest before offsetting capital gains; otherwise, unused capital losses can be carried over but do not offset ordinary income.
There is no standard deduction. The only federal itemized deductions which are allowed as Massachusetts deductions are medical expenses and employee business expenses; these are only deductible for a taxpayer who itemized deductions and deducted them, although employee business expenses are deductible in full if they, combined with other miscellaneous deductions, exceeded 2% of AGI; in addition, most federal adjustments to income (HSAs, student loan interest, and so on) are deductible. 401k and employer plan contributions are deductible, but IRA contributions and self-employed retirement plans, including SEP, SIMPLE, and Solo 401(k) plans of sole proprietors are not deductible; non-deductible portion is not taxed upon withdrawal[https://www.mass.gov/info-details/tax-treatment-of-non-government-pensions-in-massachusetts#:~:text=Contributing%20to%20a%20traditional%20IRA,adjusted%20gross%20income%20(AGI).]. There are also deductions for 50% of rent paid (up to $3,000 per return), Social Security and Medicare taxes paid (up to $2000 per person)[https://www.mass.gov/info-details/massachusetts-social-security-fica-and-medicare-deduction], college tuition in excess of 25% of Massachusetts AGI[https://www.mass.gov/info-details/massachusetts-education-related-tax-deductions#:~:text=Massachusetts%20allows%20a%20deduction%20for,degree%2C%20diploma%2C%20or%20certificate.], undergraduate student loan interest even if not federally deductible[https://www.mass.gov/info-details/massachusetts-education-related-tax-deductions#:~:text=The%20deduction%20is%20allowed%20for,subject%20to%20taxpayer%20income%20limitations.], and up to $750 per person in transit passes or tolls over $150.
For qualifying taxpayers, effective 2023, 40% of federal earned income credit is allowed as a state credit[https://www.mass.gov/info-details/earned-income-tax-credit-eitc]. There is a valuable senior ''Circuit Breaker'' Credit. You do not have to have tax due to qualify (it is a refundable credit).<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.mass.gov/info-details/massachusetts-senior-circuit-breaker-tax-credit| title=Massachusetts Senior Circuit Breaker Tax Credit | publisher=Mass.gov| date=July 10, 2024| accessdate=August 20, 2024}}</ref> if you have low taxable income, you pay rent or property tax, and are age 65 or more at the close of the tax year[https://www.mass.gov/info-details/massachusetts-senior-circuit-breaker-tax-credit].
Massachusetts residents saving in the U.Fund 529 plan can claim a MA state income tax deduction of up to $1,000 for single filers and up to $2,000 for married persons filing jointly[https://www.mefa.org/save/u-fund-college-investing-plan#:~:text=Savers%20can%20claim%20a%20MA,for%20married%20persons%20filing%20jointly.].
====Michigan==== [https://www.michigan.gov/taxes Michigan] — Michigan has a flat state income tax. [https://www.kiplinger.com/state-by-state-guide-taxes/michigan#:~:text=Michigan%20income%20tax%20rate%202024&text=For%202023%2C%20Michigan%20reduced%20its,tax%20rate%20returns%20to%204.25%25.]. There are no itemized deductions; there is a 50% tax credit for small contributions to certain Michigan charities, and a partial tax credit for income tax paid to a city in Michigan. Capital gains on Treasury bonds are not taxed; capital gains from funds holding these bonds are taxable. There is a homestead property tax credit for low-income homeowners and renters. 6% of the federal earned income credit is available as a state credit. Michigan House Bill 4001 (signed March 9, 2023) has changed the taxation of retirement income.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.michigan.gov/taxes/iit/retirement-and-pension-benefits| title=Retirement and Pension Benefits| publisher=Michigan Department of Treasury| accessdate=August 20, 2024}}</ref>
The previous law created three retirement income tax systems depending on year of birth. For married couples the controlling year of birth is that of the older spouse. The 2023 law creates a phase-in of the rules for the oldest retirees; by 2026, the tiers will be gone.
In 2023, 2024, and 2025, retirees born in or before 1958. 1962, and 1966 respectively have the choice of 25%, 50%, or 75% of the benefits from pre-1946 retirees, or the benefits under the previous law. In 2026, all taxpayers 67 or older can use the full pre-1946 exclusion.
Most future retirees (born after 1952) will be able to reduce their Michigan taxable income by the larger of (1) a Personal Exemption plus their federally taxable Social Security income, or (2) an Income Deduction of $20,000 per person starting at age 67. However this Income Deduction is not inflation indexed, while the Personal Exemption and Social Security benefits are increased for inflation. Consequently the Income Deduction will become negligible over time.
People born between 1946 and 1952 get all three of the above income reductions (Personal Exemption, taxable Social Security, and Income Deduction starting at age 67). Before age 67, they can also use a partial Retirement Income Deduction (RID) of $20,000 per person, which is not inflation adjusted. The RID covers all income from pensions and traditional IRAs. Only a portion of the income from 401(k) and 403(b) plan withdrawals qualifies for the RID: * Employer contributions qualify * Employee contributions made to earn employer matching contributions also qualify.
People born before 1946 are not eligible for the $20,000 per person Income Deduction. Instead, they receive a full Retirement Income Deduction of $56,961 per person (in 2012 dollars), doubled for married filing jointly, which is increased with inflation. They also receive the Personal Exemption and taxable Social Security reduction to their Michigan taxable income.
====Minnesota==== [https://www.revenue.state.mn.us/minnesota-income-tax-rates-and-brackets Minnesota] — Minnesota has a graduated state income tax. Effective 2023, Social Security is taxable, but for those with AGI $100,000 MFJ or less ($70k single) Social Security is not taxable. The exemption phases out as AGI increases[https://www.revenue.state.mn.us/mndor-pp/19941?type]. Most retirement and pension income is taxable, with some exceptions for public pensions. [https://www.kiplinger.com/state-by-state-guide-taxes/minnesota].
MN enacted a new tax on net investment income, starting in tax year 2024. Net investment income includes but is not limited to interest, dividends, capital gains, rental and royalty income, and other similar income. It is reduced by certain deductions, like investment interest expenses, investment advisory and brokerage fees, and similar expenses. This new tax is imposed on individuals, estates, and trusts with more than $1 million of net investment income in the tax year. The tax rate is 1% on the net investment income over $1 million[https://www.revenue.state.mn.us/mndor-pp/19941?type]. Minnesota taxpayers can reduce their state taxable income up to $3,000 if married filing jointly ($1,500 filing single) for contributions made into a Minnesota 529 College Savings Plan[https://www.mnsaves.org/learn/how-does-a-529-plan-work].
====Mississippi==== [https://www.dor.ms.gov/individual/individual-income-tax-faqs Mississippi] — Retirement income, including qualified distributions from retirement accounts are not taxed in Mississippi, which is a consideration in traditional vs Roth decisions. Mississippi has a single income tax rate on income over $10,000. The rate is scheduled to decrease each year until 2026.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.dor.ms.gov/individual/tax-rates| title=Tax Rates, Exemptions, & Deductions | publisher=Mississippi DOR| accessdate=August 20, 2024}}</ref>
====Missouri==== [https://dor.mo.gov/taxation/individual/tax-types/income/ Missouri] — Missouri has a graduated state income tax [https://www.kiplinger.com/state-by-state-guide-taxes/missouri#:~:text=Missouri%20Income%20Tax%20Range,also%20impose%20an%20earnings%20tax.)]. Kansas City and St. Louis also have a local income tax[https://states.aarp.org/missouri/state-taxes-guide#:~:text=Missouri's%20individual%20income%20tax%20rates,1%20percent%20local%20income%20tax.]. Social Security is tax exempt effective 2024. Public Pensions are tax exempt. Private pensions and other retirement income is typically taxable. Missouri eliminated state capital gains taxes as of 2025.<ref>[https://www.kiplinger.com/taxes/another-state-eliminates-capital-gains-tax Kiplinger-Another State Eliminates Capital Gains Tax in 2025: What’s Next?]</ref> Missouri 529s have a state tax deduction for Missouri residents (up to $8,000 per person, or $16,000 if you're married filing jointly) [https://www.missourimost.org/home/529-features/tax-advantages.html#:~:text=Other%20tax%20advantages%20of%20the,when%20used%20for%20qualified%20expenses]. Missouri places a fiduciary tax on certain trust income[https://dor.mo.gov/taxation/individual/tax-types/fiduciary/].
====Montana==== [https://mtrevenue.gov/taxes/individual-income-tax/ Montana] — Montana has a graduated state income tax[https://www.kiplinger.com/state-by-state-guide-taxes/montana]. Social Security is taxable retirement income in Montana unless your federal AGI falls below a certain threshold. All Social Security income is deductible if you’re a single filer with an AGI less than $25,000 or joint filers with an AGI less than $32,000. For single filers with an AGI between $25,000 and $34,000 or joint filers with an AGI between $32,000 and $44,000, 50 percent of Social Security is deductible. Anyone earning more than that can only deduct 15 percent of their Social Security[https://www.unbiased.com/discover/taxes/montana-tax-guide#:~:text=Social%20Security%20is%20taxable%20retirement,an%20AGI%20less%20than%20%2432%2C000.]. Contributions you make to Achieve Montana 529 plans may be eligible as a yearly deduction of up to $3,000 per taxpayer per year ($6,000 for those married, filing jointly)[https://achievemontana.com/what-is-a-529-plan/]
====Nebraska==== [https://revenue.nebraska.gov/ Nebraska] — Nebraska has a graduated state income tax[https://www.kiplinger.com/state-by-state-guide-taxes/nebraska][https://revenue.nebraska.gov/sites/default/files/doc/research/chronology/4-607table1_0.pdf]. Nebraska no longer taxes Social Security[https://governor.nebraska.gov/press/governor-pillen-signs-historic-tax-cuts-package]. Nebraska 529 Account owners are eligible to receive a Nebraska state income tax deduction of up to $10,000 ($5,000 if married, filing separately) for contributions made to their own NEST 529 accounts[https://treasurer.nebraska.gov/news/default.aspx?story=592].
====Nevada==== [https://tax.nv.gov/about-nevada-department-of-taxation/income-tax-in-nevada/#:~:text=Key%20Points%3A,sales%20tax%20and%20property%20tax. Nevada] — Nevada has no income tax on individuals
====New Hampshire==== [https://www.revenue.nh.gov/taxes-glance/interest-dividends-tax New Hampshire] — New Hampshire has no personal income tax on earned income. There is an interest and dividends tax through 2024. The interest and dividends tax was assessed at 5% for tax periods ending prior to December 31, 2023. Recently enacted legislation phased out the interest and dividends tax starting at 4% for taxable periods ending on or after December 31, 2023, and 3% for taxable periods ending on or after December 31, 2024. This tax is then repealed for taxable periods beginning after December 31, 2024.
====New Jersey==== [https://www.state.nj.us/treasury/taxation/ New Jersey] — New Jersey has a graduated state income tax. Social Security is not taxed. No deduction for IRAs, or for any retirement plans other than 401(k) plans; non-deductible portion is not taxed on withdrawal. Health Savings Accounts are not recognized; contributions are not deductible and income earned is taxed.
Capital losses exceeding gains may not offset ordinary income nor be carried over to future years.
Medical insurance paid by [[payroll deduction]] (Section 125 or "cafeteria" plan) is taxed. Income and capital gains on New Jersey and Treasury bonds (including the prorated portion of a fund with 80% of its assets tax-exempt) are not taxed, even in IRAs.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.nj.gov/treasury/taxation/pdf/pubs/tgi-ee/git2.pdf| title=Tax Topic Bulletin GIT-2, IRA Withdrawals| publisher=New Jersey Division of Taxation| accessdate=August 20, 2024}}</ref>
For taxpayers over 62, for a taxpayer with gross income at most $100,000, married couples exclude all retirement income from tax, and singles exclude up to $75,000. For gross income between $100,001 and $125,000, the exclusion is 50% married/37.5% single of all retirement income (so that the excluded amount on $100,000 of retirement income for both married and singles is halved when the gross income exceeds $100,001); between $125,001 and $150,000, the exclusion is 25% married/18.75% single. This exemption applies to pension, annuity, and IRA withdrawals, and also to all other income as long as earned income is at most $3,000[https://nj.gov/treasury/unclaimed-property/treasury/taxation/njit7.shtml].
Deductions allowed only for medical expenses in excess of 2% of income, and property taxes (also 18% of rent paid by renters assumed to be property tax)[https://www.nj.gov/treasury/taxation/njit13.shtml][https://www.nj.gov/treasury/taxation/njit35.shtml].
40% of federal earned income credit allowed as state credit for 2023. Part-year resident taxes are not prorated[https://www.nj.gov/treasury/taxation/eitc/howmucheitc.shtml][https://www.nj.gov/treasury/news/2024/02052024.shtml].
Effective 2022, New Jersey 529 contributions are tax deductible up to $10,000, provided gross income does not exceed $200,000[https://www.nj.gov/treasury/taxation/individuals/collegededuction.shtml#:~:text=NJ%20Taxation&text=Prior%20to%20Tax%20Year%202022,used%20for%20qualified%20educational%20expenses.].
====New Mexico==== [https://www.tax.newmexico.gov/individuals/personal-income-tax-information-overview/ New Mexico] — New Mexico has a graduated state income tax[https://www.kiplinger.com/state-by-state-guide-taxes/new-mexico]. As of 2022, New Mexico does not tax most Social Security benefits. Single and married filing separately filers can make up to $100,000 without having their Social Security taxed. All other filers can make up to $150,000. Other retirement income is partially taxed, but some exemptions and deductions do exist for taxpayers over 65. Contributions to New Mexico 529 plans are 100% deductible from New Mexico State income tax for New Mexico residents[https://hed.nm.gov/financial-aid/new-mexico-529-college-savings-plan]
====New York==== [https://www.tax.ny.gov/pit/ New York] — New York has graduated state income tax[https://www.kiplinger.com/state-by-state-guide-taxes/new-york]. Social Secutity is not taxed. $20,000 per person of pension benefits (including IRAs) is not taxed after age 59-1/2[https://www.tax.ny.gov/pit/file/information_for_seniors.htm][https://www.tax.ny.gov/pdf/publications/income/pub36.pdf]. Itemized deductions only allowed if deductions were itemized on the federal return[https://www.tax.ny.gov/pit/file/itemized-deductions.htm][https://www.tax.ny.gov/forms/current-forms/it/it196i.htm]; standard deduction may be taken even if deductions were itemized on the federal return. All itemized deductions are reduced for taxpayers earning over $100,000 single/$200,000 joint, with considerable reductions at higher levels[https://accountants.intuit.com/support/en-us/help-article/state-taxes/itemized-vs-standard-deductions-ny-form-201/L0qtPpZVu_US_en_US#:~:text=New%20York's%20tax%20law%20limits,married%20taxpayers%20with%20NYAGI%20%3E%20%24200%2C000].
$5,000 per person of contributions to the New York 529 plan is subtracted from income[https://www.nyc.gov/site/opa/my-pay/nys-529-college-savings-program.page#:~:text=Tax%20Advantages%20of%20the%20Program&text=For%20example%2C%20tuition%2C%20fees%2C,for%20married%20couples%20filing%20jointly).]. Up to $10,000 per student in undergraduate tuition is allowed as an itemized deduction, or $200 or 4% of tuition may be taken as a credit; payments from a 529 plan may be used for the credit or deduction.
New York City and Yonkers charge an income tax that is paid with the state tax; tax paid to another state or an out-of-state county or city can be taken as a credit against state tax but not city tax. Credit is allowed for tax paid to Canadian provinces (but not to Canada itself).
Child tax credit allowed, but only for children over 4; it is usually 33% of the federal tax credit for those children[https://www.tax.ny.gov/pit/credits/empire_state_child_credit.htm].
30% of federal earned income credit allowed as state credit, and another 5% in New York City[https://www.tax.ny.gov/pit/credits/earned_income_credit.htm].
====North Carolina ==== [https://www.ncdor.gov/taxes-forms/individual-income-tax/ North Carolina] — North Carolina has a [https://www.ncdor.gov/taxes-forms/tax-rate-schedules/ flat tax rate] of 4.5% in 2024, 4.25% in 2025, and 3.99% for 2026 and later. There is a choice between [https://www.ncdor.gov/north-carolina-standard-deduction-or-north-carolina-itemized-deductions/ standard or itemized deductions].
Social Security and Railroad Retirement benefits [https://www.ncdor.gov/taxes-forms/individual-income-tax/social-security-and-railroad-retirement-benefits/ are not taxed]. Any portion of such income that was taxed at a Federal level is taken as a deduction to Federal AGI. Other retirement income is generally taxable.
[https://www.ncdor.gov/interest-income-obligations-other-states/ Interest on notes and bonds from states other than North Carolina] are treated as an addition to Federal AGI. Interest from notes and bonds from Guam, Puerto Rico, and the U.S. Virgin Islands are not subject to this requirement.
There are tax benefits for [https://www.ncdor.gov/taxes-forms/individual-income-tax/military-retirement/ military retirees].
The [https://www.ncdor.gov/bailey-decision-concerning-federal-state-and-local-retirement-benefits Bailey court decision] limits how much the state can tax certain retirees, including federal pensioners with 5 or more years of creditable service as of August 12, 1989.
North Carolina [https://www.cfnc.org/news/how-does-an-nc-529-tax-deduction-work/#:~:text=Just%20as%20there%20are%20no,contributions%20to%20NC%20529%20Accounts. does not offer a deduction for 529 contributions].
====North Dakota==== [https://www.tax.nd.gov/individual North Dakota] — North Dakota has graduated state income tax. In 2023 they moved from five to [https://www.tax.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/newsletters/2023-income-tax-newsletter.pdf three brackets]. North Dakota has [https://www.kiplinger.com/state-by-state-guide-taxes/north-dakota no taxes on Social Security]. The state 529 plan offers [https://www.ndpers.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/events/college-save-slides.pdf a tax deduction] for contributions of $5,000 for singles and $10,000 for married couples.
====Ohio==== [https://tax.ohio.gov/individual/filing-season-central/individual Ohio] — Ohio has a [https://www.kiplinger.com/state-by-state-guide-taxes/ohio graduated state income tax]. Cities and school districts in Ohio can also impose local income taxes. Social Security is not taxed. Taxpayers can [https://tax.ohio.gov/help-center/faqs/income-529-plan-account-deduction/income-529-plan-account-deduction deduct contributions] they made to a 529 savings plan up to $4,000 per beneficiary per year. The deduction is not limited to the savings plan owner or beneficiary. Instead, any taxpayer who makes a contribution is entitled to the deduction. Contributions exceeding the $4,000 limitation may be carried forward and deducted on future year's returns until fully used, subject to the annual limitation of $4,000 per beneficiary. Beginning with tax year 2023, contributions to any state's 529 plan are eligible for this deduction.
====Oklahoma==== [https://oktap.tax.ok.gov/oktap/web/_/ Oklahoma] — Oklahoma has a [https://www.kiplinger.com/state-by-state-guide-taxes/oklahoma graduated state income tax]. Social Security is not taxed. [https://www.oklahoma529.com/resources/faq#:~:text=Oklahoma%20residents%20can%20deduct%20a,year%20for%20a%20single%20return. Oklahoma 529s] have a deduction of up to $10,000 per year for a single return and $20,000 per year for a joint return.
====Oregon==== [https://www.oregon.gov/dor/programs/individuals/pages/pit.aspx/ Oregon] — Oregon has a graduated and [https://www.kiplinger.com/state-by-state-guide-taxes/oregon comparatively high state income tax], up to 9.9% over $125,000 as of 2024. There may be additional local income taxes. Tax deferral strategies such as traditional 401ks, IRAs, HSAs and deferred compensation plans take on added importance. Social Security is not taxed. All Oregon residents are eligible to receive a refundable state income tax [https://www.oregoncollegesavings.com/faqs/is-there-an-oregon-state-income-tax-credit credit] up to $360 for joint filers and up to $180 for single filers on contributions made to an Oregon 529 College Savings Plan account.
====Pennsylvania==== [https://www.revenue.pa.gov/TaxTypes/PIT/Pages/default.aspx Pennsylvania] — Pennsylvania has a flat state income tax. Pennsylvania law allows deductions for medical and health savings account contributions, and IRC Section 529 tuition account program contributions (not IRA or 401(k) contributions). There is no standard deduction or personal exemption.
Capital losses may not be deducted against capital gain distributions from mutual funds, only against actual capital gains, and may not be carried over from previous years.
Social Security is excluded as income. Contributions to IRAs and employer retirement plans are generally [https://www.revenue.pa.gov/FormsandPublications/FormsforIndividuals/PIT/Documents/rev-636.pdf not deductible]. Retirement plans withdrawals, pensions, and IRAs are not taxed if withdrawn after meeting the age requirements; otherwise, any net gains (such as withdrawals from an IRA before 59-1/2) are taxed. ([https://www.revenue.pa.gov/FormsandPublications/PAPersonalIncomeTaxGuide/Documents/PITGuide_GrossCompensation.pdf PA PIT Guide: Gross Compensation] contains detailed tables of what is included and excluded.)
====Rhode Island==== [https://tax.ri.gov/tax-sections/personal-income-tax Rhode Island] — Rhode Island has a [https://www.kiplinger.com/state-by-state-guide-taxes/rhode-island graduated state income tax]. For taxpayers who have reached Social Security retirement age, as of 2023 the first $20,000 of retirement income including public and private pensions and employer retirement account distributions [https://tax.ri.gov/sites/g/files/xkgbur541/files/2023-04/PUB_2023-01_pension_income_guide.pdf are tax exempt], and $40,000 married filing jointly, subject to [https://tax.ri.gov/sites/g/files/xkgbur541/files/2024-03/PUB_2024-01_retirement_income_guide.pdf AGI limits]. The 2023 AGI limits (which are adjusted for inflation) are $101,000 for singles and $126,250 for married filing jointly. All forms of personal IRAs do not get this exemption. Social Security income is also exempt, subject to the same AGI limits as the retirement income exemption. Rhode Island 529 plans are able to [https://treasury.ri.gov/programs/collegebound-saver-529-plan deduct up to $1000] of contributions.
====South Carolina==== [https://dor.sc.gov/tax/individual-income South Carolina] — South Carolina has a [https://www.kiplinger.com/state-by-state-guide-taxes/south-carolina graduated income tax]. Social Security is not taxable. [https://dor.sc.gov/resources-site/media-site/Pages/SCDOR-offers-tax-tips-for-retirees-and-those-65-or-older.aspx Up to $10,000 of other retirement income is tax deductible for those 65 and older, and $3000 of retirement is deductible for those under 65]. South Carolina retirees 65 and older are also eligible for a $15,000 deduction against any income. [https://treasurer.sc.gov/about-us/newsroom/time-to-boost-savings-and-lower-taxes/ South Carolina allows residents to deduct 100% of their 529 contributions to a Future Scholar account].
====South Dakota==== [https://dor.sd.gov/individuals/taxes/ South Dakota] — South Dakota does not have a personal income tax.
====Tennessee==== [https://www.tn.gov/revenue/taxes.html Tennessee] — Tennessee has no personal income tax.
====Texas==== [https://comptroller.texas.gov/taxes/ Texas] — Texas does not have a personal income tax.
====Utah==== [https://incometax.utah.gov/ Utah] — Utah has a [https://www.kiplinger.com/state-by-state-guide-taxes/utah flat state income tax]. Social Security is taxable to the same extent as federally, although some taxpayers may be eligible for a social security non-refundable [https://incometax.utah.gov/credits/ss-benefits tax credit]. Most other retirement income is typically taxable. Utah residents who contribute to an Utah 529 plan are eligible for a non-refundable [https://my529.org/benefits-of-my529/tax-advantages/ tax credit ]of up to $213 in 2023.
====Vermont==== [https://tax.vermont.gov/individuals/personal-income-tax Vermont] — Vermont has a [https://www.kiplinger.com/state-by-state-guide-taxes/vermont graduated state income tax]. Social Security benefits are exempt for joint filers with an adjusted gross income (AGI) of $65,000 or less. Vermont offers a deduction of up to $10,000 for some types of retirement income subject to income constraints. An income tax [https://www.vheip.org/benefits-tax-advantages/#vermont-state-income-tax-credit credit] is available to residents contributing to the Vermont 529 program.
====Virginia==== [https://www.tax.virginia.gov/ Virginia] — Virginia has a [https://www.kiplinger.com/state-by-state-guide-taxes/virginia#:~:text=Income%20tax%20rates%20for%202024,from%202%25%20to%205.75%25. graduated state income tax]. Social Security and Tier 1 Railroad Retirement are not taxed. Capital gains on bonds exempt from Virginia tax (Treasuries and in-state munis) are not taxed. There is an unusually large tax deduction of $12,000 for taxpayers 65 or over; for taxpayers born in 1939 or later, this deduction is phased out by $1 for every $1 of income over $50,000 single/$75,000 married.
You must use the standard or itemized deduction for Virginia according to which one you used on the federal return. Low income taxpayers may be eligible for one of the following [https://www.tax.virginia.gov/low-income-individuals-credit credits] - a $300 credit per person for a family with income below the poverty line, 15% of the federal earned income tax credit as a refundable credit or 20% of the federal earned income credit as a non-refundable credit.
Virginia taxpayers may open a [https://www.tax.virginia.gov/first-time-home-buyer-savings-account-subtraction first-time homebuyer savings account], which works analogously to a 529 college savings plan for Virginia state tax purposes; income is exempt from Virginia state tax, but the gain is subject to tax and penalty if the account is not used for a first-time home purchase in Virginia.
Virginia529 account owners who are Virginia taxpayers may [https://www.virginia529.com/learn/tax-benefits/ deduct contributions up to $4,000] per account per year with an unlimited carryforward to future tax years, subject to certain restrictions. Those age 70 and above may deduct the entire amount contributed to a Virginia529 account in one year.
====Washington==== [https://dor.wa.gov/taxes-rates/other-taxes/capital-gains-tax Washington] — Washington does not have a personal income tax, but does have a 7% capital gains tax for amounts over $262,000(as of 2023). This tax was ruled as an excise tax, not an income tax.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.lanepowell.com/Our-Insights/262901/Demystifying-Washington-States-New-Capital-Gains-Tax| title=Demystifying Washington State’s New Capital Gains Tax - Lane Powell PC| publisher=Lane Powell| accessdate=August 20, 2024}}</ref> As of November 2024 there is a pending initiative to repeal this tax.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://washingtonstatestandard.com/2024/05/06/wa-decides-initiative-2109-to-repeal-the-states-capital-gains-tax/| title=WA decides: Initiative 2109 to repeal the state’s capital gains tax| publisher=Washington State Standard| date=May 6, 2024| accessdate=August 20, 2024}}</ref>
====West Virginia==== [https://tax.wv.gov/Pages/default.aspx West Virginia] — West Virginia has a [https://www.kiplinger.com/state-by-state-guide-taxes/west-virginia graduated income tax]. Social Security is partially taxable in 2024 but the tax is being [https://states.aarp.org/west-virginia/tax-social-security-benefits phased out]. All contributions to WV 529s are [https://529s.com/state-plans/west-virginia-529-plan/#:~:text=Tax%20Benefits%3A%20Good%20news%20for,from%20your%20adjusted%20gross%20income. tax deductible].
====Wisconsin==== [https://www.revenue.wi.gov/Pages/FAQS/pcs-taxrates.aspx Wisconsin] — Wisconsin has a graduated state income tax. Social Security is not taxed. Most other retirement income is taxed, but starting in 2025 taxpayers age 67 and older in the state [https://taxfoundation.org/blog/wisconsin-budget-retirement-income-tax-relief/ may deduct up to $24,000 single / $48,000 MFJ] of certain retirement income.<ref>[https://tax.thomsonreuters.com/news/wisconsin-governor-tony-evers-signs-2025-2027-budget-bill/#:~:text=Fong,%2C%20or%20as%20otherwise%20indicated.%29 Wisconsin Governor Tony Evers Signs 2025-2027 Budget Bill]</ref>
[https://dfi.wi.gov/Pages/EducationalServices/CollegeSavingsCareerPlanning/CollegeSavingsProgram.aspx A Wisconsin state income tax deduction for contributions made to a Wisconsin 529 plan] is available to any Wisconsin taxpayer, not just the 529 plan account owner of $5,000 per beneficiary for single filers or married filing joint, OR $2,500 per beneficiary for married filing separate.
====Wyoming==== [https://revenue.wyo.gov/ Wyoming] — Wyoming has no income tax.
==Notes== ===For wiki editors - issues to check when adding a state to the list=== Here are some of the more common issues which should be mentioned: *No income tax, or tax applied only to some types of income (investments but not salary). *Municipal bonds from other states not taxed. *State taxes some income excluded from Federal income on W-2 (for example, 401(k) or 403(b) contributions). *Tax exemptions for Social Security or retirement income. *Taxation of [[Health savings account]]s. *Minimum fraction of income or assets in tax-exempt assets for mutual funds to be exempt from state taxes. *No standard deduction. *Only specific items may be deducted, rather than most Federal itemized deductions. *Significant additional deductions such as Federal tax. *Taxpayers must itemize state deductions if they itemize Federal deductions, or must take state standard deduction if they take Federal standard deduction. *Different types of income taxed at different rates. *Credit for taxes paid to foreign countries or localities in those countries. *Earned income credit. *Part-year resident income is not prorated, in states with progressive tax rates. (If the tax rate is flat, proration is irrelevant, as the tax on $20,000 is 20% of the tax on $100,000.)
Keep the [[#Specific issues for investors|Specific issues for investors]] section short. Include only issues relevant to a large number of investors, such as non-deductibility of mortgage interest or taxability of different types of investment income. The [[#Tax details|Tax details]] section, which is the last section, can be long if there are important details. For simplicity and to reduce the number of changes needed annually, avoid listing specific numbers (such as the amount of a personal exemption, or the tax rate) unless they are very large or otherwise significant.

Includes numerous summary tables for state-by-state comparison of taxes, revenue, burdens, and other topics such as a list of [https://taxadmin.org/2024-sales-tax-holidays/ State Sales Tax Holidays]. *[https://taxfoundation.org/data/all/state/state-income-tax-rates-2024/ State Tax Rates] from [https://taxfoundation.org/ Tax Foundation] *[https://www.kiplinger.com/retirement/602202/taxes-in-retirement-how-all-50-states-tax-retirees State taxes on Retirees all 50 states] from [https://www.kiplinger.com/ Kiplinger]
