align="center"| 40% |- | 2025 | align="center"| $13.99 million | align="center"| 40% |- | 2026 | align="center"| $15.00 million | align="center"| 40% |} ===Portability for married couples=== A surviving spouse can retain use of any unused portion of a deceased spouse's individual tax exemption. This feature is known as ''portability''.{{cite web| url=https://www.actec.org/resource-center/video/what-is-portability-for-estate-and-gift-tax/| title=What is Portability for Estate and Gift Tax?| publisher=The American College of Trust and Estate Counsel| author1=Jean Gordon Carter| author2=Stephen W. Murphy |accessdate=July 27, 2025}}{{cite web| url=https://www.schwab.com/learn/story/how-portability-helps-couples-reduce-estate-taxes| title=How Portability Can Help Minimize Estate Taxes| publisher=Charles Schwab| accessdate=July 4, 2025}} Married couples can transfer an unlimited amount of assets to each other during life or at death entirely gift and estate tax-free. Using portability, when one spouse dies, the surviving spouse can add the unused portion of their deceased spouse's exemption to their own lifetime exemption. This gives the couple a total of $27.98 million in 2025 and $30 million in 2026,{{cite web| url=https://www.thetaxadviser.com/news/2025/jun/details-of-tax-changes-in-senate-reconciliation-bill/| title=Tax provisions in the One Big Beautiful Bill Act| publisher=The Tax Advisor| author=Alistair M. Nevius, J.D. |accessdate=July 27, 2025}} split between them in any way that provides the greatest tax benefit. Portability is '''not automatic.''' You must elect to port over your deceased spouse's remaining exemption by filing a U.S. Estate, Gift, and Generation-Skipping Return ([https://www.irs.gov/forms-pubs/about-form-706 Form 706]).{{Forum link|title=‪ Filing Federal Estate Tax Return to Get Portability‬.|p= 6756481 |author=Bruce Steiner|date=July 2, 2022}}. Before portability became permanent,{{cite web| url=https://www.barrattorneys.com/blog/estate-tax-changes-portability-becomes-permanent/| title=Estate Tax Law Changes: How Portability Became Permanent| publisher=Barr & Douds Attorneys| accessdate=July 4, 2025}} estates could accomplish this using [https://www.investopedia.com/terms/c/creditsheltertrust.asp credit shelter trusts], [[Trusts#Revocable_Living_Trusts_(RLTs)|bypass trusts]], and similar. Even if you don’t expect to end up with anywhere near the current estate tax threshold amount of wealth, it is generally a good idea for any material estate to file a form 706 as a form of insurance.[Https://www.bogleheads.org/forum/viewtopic.php?t=381048 Filing Federal Estate Tax Return to Get Portability] Estate tax limits frequently change, or you may live longer and experience more wealth appreciation than expected. In addition, particular care is recommended in filling the form out, as mistakes can be costly[https://www.wsj.com/personal-finance/taxes/estate-taxes-portability-planning-mistakes-26111632?mod=taxes_trendingnow_article_pos1 The Estate Tax Mistake That Can Cost Families Millions][https://www.bogleheads.org/forum/viewtopic.php?t=459507 wsj: the estate tax mistake that can cost families millions]. In most cases it is advisable to have an estate planning attorney to complete this task. Most states that levy a [[#State_estate_and_inheritance_taxes|state estate tax]] '''do not''' have portability. If you expect your estate to owe state estate tax in a non-portability state and portability would be a benefit, consider the use of trusts to achieve the same effect. ====Example==== This example assumes the $15 million exemption for deaths occurring during 2026. Dr. Smith leaves $9 million to his widow; no estate tax is owed because property left to a spouse is tax-free. The widow then dies, leaving $28 million (her own $19 million plus the $9 million she inherited from her husband) to their children. Her estate will not owe any estate tax, even though the estate is over the exemption amount, because the estate can use $6 million of the husband's unused exemption. To take advantage of this provision, an estate tax return must be filed when the first spouse dies—even if no tax will be due. ===The taxable estate=== If the gross estate is subject to estate tax, the following deductions are allowable for determining the taxable estate:{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/statistics/soi-tax-stats-estate-tax-study-terms-and-concepts#T| title=SOI Tax Stats - Estate tax study terms and concepts| publisher=IRS| accessdate=July 4, 2025}} *'''Marital Deduction''': One of the primary deductions for married decedents is the Marital Deduction. All property that is included in the gross estate and passes to the surviving spouse is eligible for the marital deduction. The property must pass "outright." In some cases, certain life estates also qualify for the marital deduction. The marital deduction is not allowed to non-citizen spouses. (I.R.C. § 2056(a)){{#tag:ref|A non-citizen spouse can gain the benefits of the marital deduction by becoming a citizen of the United States. Estate values exceeding the personal exemption can also be left to a non-citizen spouse in a special type of trust, known as a Q-DOT ( "qualified domestic trust"). These trusts have special rules regarding beneficiary restrictions, estate tax obligations on distributions of trust principal, and are complex legal documents that must be created by an experienced estate lawyer.{{cite web| url=https://www.nolo.com/legal-encyclopedia/estate-planning-when-you-re-married-noncitizen.html| title=Estate Planning for Noncitizen Spouses| publisher=Nolo| accessdate=July 4, 2025}}|group="note"}} *'''Charitable Deduction''': If the decedent leaves property to a [[Charity selection links|qualifying charity]], it is deductible from the gross estate. (I.R.C. § 2055(a)) *'''Mortgages and Debt'''. *'''Funeral Expenses.''' *'''Administration expenses of the estate.''' *'''Losses during estate administration.''' *'''State Death Taxes.''' ===When to file=== You must file Form 706 to report estate and/or Generation-Skipping Transfer (GST) tax within 9 months after the date of the decedent's death.{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/forms-pubs/about-form-706| title=About Form 706, United States Estate (and Generation-Skipping Transfer) Tax Return| publisher=IRS| accessdate=July 4, 2025}} Nonresident aliens do not use Form 706, but instead use Form 706-NA.{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/forms-pubs/about-form-706-na| title=About Form 706-NA, United States Estate (and Generation-Skipping Transfer) Tax Return| publisher=IRS| accessdate=July 4, 2025}} ==State estate and inheritance taxes== ===State estate taxes=== For U.S. citizens, the federal estate tax applies only to very large estates (above $13.99 million in 2025). But many estates that do not owe federal tax ''do'' owe a separate state estate tax. It depends on where the deceased person lived and owned property.{{cite web| url=https://www.nolo.com/legal-encyclopedia/state-estate-taxes.html| title=States With Estate Taxes| publisher=Nolo| accessdate=July 4, 2025}} As of 2025, thirteen states have an estate tax. Although the rules can vary by state, typically the following assets are included in the gross estate on which state estate taxes are calculated: *For residents of the state, their taxable estate includes all intangible property (bank accounts, investments, life insurance, etc.) and all real and tangible property located in the state. Out-of-state real and tangible property is typically excluded from taxation. *For non-residents, their taxable estate includes only real and tangible property located in the state, but not intangible property. Note that even if you do not reside in a state that assesses an estate tax, you might need to file an estate tax return and even owe estate taxes if you own real or tangible property in a state that does. In most states with an estate tax, the exemption is '''not''' [[#Portability_for_married_couples|portable]] between spouses like the federal exemption. If you expect to owe state estate taxes in a state without portability, consider additional planning, such as with [[trusts]]. The states imposing estate taxes are summarized in the tables below. Because estate and inheritance taxes are subject to frequent change, a link to each state's most relevant estate tax website is provided. Also included are links to a summary of each state's estate and inheritance tax, courtesy of the Nolo legal site. Note that there are nuances to how these taxes are applied, such as how the exact calculation is made, whether the exemption is portable between spouses, exclusions for certain types of property, and how states handle [[gift tax]]. {| class=wikitable style="text-align:left" |+ style="text-align: center;" | '''State Estate Taxes''' ! scope="col" style="width: 160pt;" | State [links] ! scope="col" style="width: 95pt;" | Exemption ! scope="col" style="width: 50pt;" | Portable? ! scope="col" style="width: 60pt;" | Tax rates ! Comments |- | Connecticut [http://www.ct.gov/drs/cwp/view.asp?a=1509&q=445162] [http://www.nolo.com/legal-encyclopedia/connecticut-estate-tax.html Nolo]|| Same as federal || No || 12% || |- | Delaware [http://revenue.delaware.gov/services/PIT_SvcsTemp.shtml] [http://www.nolo.com/legal-encyclopedia/delaware-estate-tax.html Nolo]|| Repealed || - || - || |- | Vermont [http://www.state.vt.us/tax/individualestate.shtml] [http://www.nolo.com/legal-encyclopedia/vermont-estate-tax.html Nolo] || $5 million (2025) || No || 16% || |- | Washington [http://dor.wa.gov/content/findtaxesandrates/othertaxes/tax_estate.aspx] [http://www.nolo.com/legal-encyclopedia/washington-estate-tax.html Nolo] || $3,000,000 (July 2025) || No || 10-'''35%''' || Note the unusually high top marginal estate tax rate for deaths occurring on or after July 1, 2025. This top rate applies to taxable estate values more than $9 million above the exemption, and when combined with the federal rate can create a marginal estate tax rate of 61%.Because state estate taxes are deductible against federal estate taxes, the combined rate can be calculated as 35% + 40%*(1-35%). |- |} ===State inheritance taxes=== The estate tax gets a lot more attention, but people who inherit property may also have to pay a separate inheritance tax, which is imposed by five states (Maryland has both estate and inheritance taxes). Typically, inheritance taxes are based on where the ''decedent'' lived, not where the heir lives. If you inherit property from someone who lived in one of these states, you may end up paying some of your inheritance in taxes.{{cite web| url=https://www.nolo.com/legal-encyclopedia/state-inheritance-taxes.html| title=Inheritance Tax: Which States Impose an Inheritance Tax| publisher=Nolo| accessdate=July 4, 2025}} But, if you live in a state with an inheritance tax and inherit assets from someone in a state with no inheritance tax, you will not owe inheritance tax except on real or tangible property they left you in your state. Inheritance tax is a state tax only; the federal government does not have an inheritance tax. Inheritance tax is imposed in addition to the federal estate tax and any state estate tax. Whether or not you will owe inheritance tax depends on how closely related you were to the person who left you money. It does not matter, in most states, how big the whole estate is or how much you inherit. You might owe state inheritance tax even if you inherit a small amount of property. If you inherit from your spouse (or registered domestic partner or civil union partner), you are exempt from inheritance tax in all states. Charitable beneficiaries may also be exempt from the tax. Depending on state law, children who inherit either pay nothing or pay low rates. Certain types of assets (for example, life insurance) may also be excluded from taxation. Although inheritance taxes are technically owed by the heir, not the estate, the estate executor is typically responsible for calculating and paying inheritance taxes before money is paid out to heirs. And, it is based on the decedent's residence, not the heirs. In these regards, estate and inheritance taxes are very similar, the main difference being: *Estate taxes get a large exemption, but the rate on assets above the exemption does not depend on who receives the inheritance - except that transfers to a surviving spouse and charitable bequests are typically excluded from taxation *Inheritance taxes get only a small exemption, or no exemption, but the rate depends on ''who'' inherits the assets, with close family members paying a low rate or being completely excluded from taxation Like state estate taxes, the details of state inheritance taxes vary by the state and can change frequently, so if you live in a state with an inheritance tax, consult that state's taxing authority for details. The table below summarizes states that currently assess an inheritance tax: {| class=wikitable style="text-align:left" |+ style="text-align: center;" | '''State Inheritance Taxes''' ! State [links] ! Exemption ! Tax rates ! Comments |- | Indiana [http://www.in.gov/dor/3509.htm] [https://www.nolo.com/legal-encyclopedia/indiana-inheritance-tax.html Nolo] || Repealed || - || |- | Iowa [http://www.iowa.gov/tax/forms/inherit.html] [https://www.nolo.com/legal-encyclopedia/iowa-inheritance-tax.html Nolo] || Repealed || - || |- | Kentucky [http://revenue.ky.gov/individual/inherittax.htm] [https://www.nolo.com/legal-encyclopedia/kentucky-inheritance-tax.html Nolo] || $1000/$500 (2025) ||| 4-16% / 6-16% || |- | Maryland [http://individuals.marylandtaxes.com/estatetax/default.asp] [http://www.nolo.com/legal-encyclopedia/maryland-inheritance-tax.html Nolo] || $1000 (2025) || 10% || |- | Nebraska [http://www.nolo.com/legal-encyclopedia/nebraska-inheritance-tax.html Nolo] || $100,000/ $40,000/ $25,000 - varies (2025) || 1%/11%/ 15% || |- | New Jersey [http://www.state.nj.us/treasury/taxation/prntinh.shtml] [http://www.nolo.com/legal-encyclopedia/new-jersey-inheritance-tax.html Nolo] ||$25,000 (spouse / children exempt) || 11-16% || |- | Pennsylvania [http://www.revenue.state.pa.us/portal/server.pt/community/inheritance_tax/11414] [http://www.nolo.com/legal-encyclopedia/pennsylvania-inheritance-tax.html Nolo] || None || 4.5% / 12%/ 15% || |} ===When to file=== Check with the relevant state, but they generally require a return filed within nine months from the date of death. Also check for a tax discount. For example, Kentucky and Pennsylvania offer a 5% discount if taxes are paid within 9 and 3 months (respectively) of the decedent's death.{{cite web| url=https://apps.legislature.ky.gov/law/statutes/statute.aspx?id=29001| title=Kentucky Revised Statute Section 140.160 (2025)| accessdate=July 27, 2025}}{{cite web| url=https://www.pa.gov/services/revenue/make-an-inheritance-tax-payment.html#:~:text=Inheritance%20Tax%20payments%20need%20to%20be%20directed%20to%20the%20Pennsylvania,5%20percent%20discount%20is%20allowed.| title=Make an Inheritance Tax Payment| publisher=Commonwealth of Pennsylvania| accessdate=July 4, 2025}} ==Estate tax planning== Although the federal estate tax exemption is large, the rate for assets above the exemption is high - 40%. When federal estate taxes are owed, it is likely millions of dollars. Some states also assess estate tax, and some have lower exclusions, as low as $1 million. State estate tax rates are typically around 16%. For those who will possibly or likely owe estate tax, additional planning is necessary. Estate tax planning typically has two goals: minimizing the tax owed, and ensuring any tax owed can be paid easily. The most obvious estate tax avoidance strategy is the use of [[#Portability_for_married_couples|portability]]. If there is a chance the surviving spouse could owe federal estate taxes, make sure to file [https://www.irs.gov/forms-pubs/about-form-706 IRS Form 706] to elect to port the deceased spouse's remaining exemption to the surviving spouse. This might be a good idea even if you doesn't expect to pay estate taxes, because the exemption could be lowered, you could have very good investment returns, you could receive an inheritance, and so on. Likewise, if the surviving spouse might owe state estate taxes in a state with a portable exemption, make sure to file the appropriate forms to transfer the unused exemption from the surviving spouse for that state. If you live in a state without a portable exemption, consider the use of [[trusts]], such as [https://www.law.cornell.edu/wex/credit_shelter_trust credit shelter trusts] or [[trusts#Disclaimer Trusts|disclaimer trusts]], or other more sophisticated estate planning techniques to achieve a similar effect. Another common estate tax avoidance strategy is to gift money while you are alive. The federal gift tax exclusion is $19,000 per person per year as of 2025, meaning gifts of up to this amount are not reportable and not potentially subject to [[gift tax]]. When the giver is married, this amount doubles, because both spouses get their own limit, and when the recipient is married, the amount doubles again because gifts can be given to both spouses. Tuition or medical expenses paid directly to the institution or provider are also exempt from gift taxes regardless of the amount. Beyond simple gifts, a competent estate planning attorney with experience planning for estate taxes in your state may be able to suggest additional, more complex, strategies to avoid estate tax. For high levels of assets, placing assets in [[trusts]], including [[trusts#Spousal Lifetime Access Trusts (SLATs)|Spousal Lifetime Access Trusts (SLATs)]], [https://www.law.cornell.edu/wex/grantor-retained_annuity_trust Grantor Retained Annuity Trusts (GRATs)] and/or [[trusts#Intentionally Defective Grantor Trusts (IDGTs)|Intentionally Defective Grantor Trusts (IDGTs)]], where future growth will occur outside your future estate, is often part of the plan. If you will owe estate tax, make sure there will be enough cash inside your estate to pay the bill. For example, if most of your assets are taxable investments and retirement accounts, and these are left directly to beneficiaries, your executor may need to recover some of these assets from your beneficiaries to pay the estate tax. If your beneficiaries do not cooperate, your executor will need to sue them to recover money, creating expense and hassle for all parties. If you do not have enough assets that will be left directly to your estate to pay the estate tax, you can designate your estate to be a partial or total beneficiary of taxable accounts or life insurance policies. Inherited retirement accounts get more favorable tax treatment by beneficiaries (spouses can treat them as their own, other beneficiaries get some type of [[Stretch IRA|stretch]]), so these should be a lower priority than taxable assets and life insurance, but they can be partly left to the estate if necessary. Several factors make estate tax planning especially difficult. Estate taxes are a highly political issue, so tax laws change frequently (there was no estate tax at all in 2010{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/businesses/small-businesses-self-employed/information-for-executors| title=Information for Executors| publisher=IRS| accessdate=June 18, 2024}}); they are likely to change again before you die. You could move to or from a state with a low estate tax exemption. And the exemption amounts are, and have historically been, indexed to inflation, so your net worth could exceed the exemption when you retire, but 30 years of spending and inflation could mean your estate ends up being far smaller than the exemption. On the other hand, with modest spending and good investments you could die with many times ''more'' money than you retired with. In the [[Safe withdrawal rates|Trinity study]], retirees ''on average'' died with 2.7 times the portfolio size they had at retirement. Make the most reasonable assumptions you can given your situation, periodically check your plan, and adjust as needed. ==Non-US residents== {{main|Nonresident alien taxation#Are nonresident aliens at risk from US estate taxes?}} The estate tax exemption for U.S. citizens is not available to nonresident aliens. For these people, the U.S. estate tax exemption is just $60 thousand.{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/individuals/international-taxpayers/some-nonresidents-with-us-assets-must-file-estate-tax-returns| title=Some nonresidents with U.S. assets must file estate tax returns| publisher=IRS| accessdate=July 4, 2025}} Investors domiciled in Canada

{{US|reason=irrelevant}}
If you have appreciated stock or mutual funds in your taxable account, you will have to pay capital-gains tax if you sell them. However, by '''donating appreciated securities''' directly to a charity you can forgo paying tax as long as you have held the securities for more than one year. (The deduction is limited to 30% of your adjusted gross income for most charities, rather than the usual 50% limit; consult your tax advisor or see [http://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/p526.pdf IRS Publication 526, Charitable Contributions] for details.)
The benefit of this type of donation is equal to the value of the tax deduction. If you donate $10,000 worth of a mutual fund and you paid $5,000 for the shares, you avoid a $5,000 long-term gain, saving $750 at the 15% tax rate. The charity, since it is tax-exempt, can sell the shares itself and pay no tax.
Note that if you have shares with a loss, you should not donate them to charity; instead, you should sell them, claiming the capital loss which will reduce your taxable income, and then donate the sale proceeds to the charity.
==Donating securities at Vanguard==
To donate mutual funds with Vanguard, go to [https://personal.vanguard.com/us/literature Forms], then under "Change of Ownership", select "Giving Fund Shares to Organizations" to give shares of mutual funds; fill out the start of the form yourself and have the charity fill out the rest of the form. If the charity does not wish to hold the fund, one of the options allows the charity to ask Vanguard to sell the fund and give it the proceeds in cash.
To donate securities from a Vanguard brokerage account, select the form "Letter of Instruction for Gifts of Securities". The charity must already have a brokerage account (not necessarily with Vanguard); you can get this information from the charity and fill out the form yourself. If the charity also has a Vanguard brokerage account, you may need to use the "Change of Ownership between Nonretirement Accounts" form.
Since you pay no tax on the donation, you would usually want to donate your lowest-basis shares which have a long-term gain. If you donate non-covered mutual fund shares, Vanguard will only provide average-cost information. If you are using [[Specific identification of shares| specific identification of shares]] for tax purposes, you need to identify which shares are being donated in the same way; send Vanguard a secure E-mail, or enclose a letter with the form, which says, "Please donate $10,000 (or 123.456 shares) from the shares purchased on 1/2/04." If you donate covered mutual fund shares, Vanguard will use your preferred lot identification method; if this is specific identification, you will have to include a similar letter because there is nowhere to select lots on the form. If you donate securities from your brokerage account, you can specify lots on the form itself, and you can use specific identification even if this is not your default method. (For example, you might want to sell shares automatically as highest-in-first-out, which usually minimizes taxes; when you donate, you would specify your lowest-basis shares.)
You cannot deduct the charitable contribution until the securities are transferred from your account; if you are donating mutual funds, you have to wait for the charity to fill out the paperwork after you send the form. Therefore, if you want to get a deduction on this year's taxes, don't make the contribution very late in the year. (In contrast, if you mail a check on December 31, it is deductible this year even if the charity deposits the check in January.)

{{US|reason=irrelevant}} Since the passage of the 1983 Amendments to the Social Security Act{{cite web|url=http://www.ssa.gov/history/1983amend.html|title=SUMMARY of P.L. 98-21, (H.R. 1900) Social Security Amendments of 1983-Signed on April 20, 1983|website=Social Security|accessdate=31 January 2015}} Social Security benefits are subject to taxation. The amount of [[Social Security]] income which is taxable depends on your Social Security income and your other income. Most high-income retirees will have 85% of Social Security benefits taxable. For lower-income retirees, less than 85% will be taxable, but many retirees in a 12% tax bracket will face a [[marginal tax rate]] much higher than 12%. Social security benefits are also taxable in some states (see Figure 1). For social security taxes imposed on earned wages, see the [[Payroll tax]] article. ==The formula== {{See also|Tax analysis#Derivation of tax rate boundaries for Social Security taxation| label 1=Derivation of tax rate boundaries for Social Security taxation}} The full rules are in IRS Publication 915.[https://www.irs.gov/publications/p915 IRS Publication 915]Calculation of taxable benefits is done in two steps. First, ''Worksheet A'' is used to determine if your benefits are taxable. If so, ''Worksheet 1 through 4'' (select one based on filing method) is used to calculate the tax. This simplification covers most cases; there are special rules if you contribute to a [[Traditional IRA]], receive retroactive payments for prior years, or file forms to exempt other income from taxation.[[Bogleheads%27 Guide to Retirement Planning]], Chapter 11; this is the main reference for the formulas above, as it is much easier to follow than the IRS guide. The relevant income for Social Security taxation includes all items which are normally part of your adjusted gross income, plus tax-exempt interest income, plus 50% of your Social Security benefits. (Historically, the 50% represents the fact that half of your Social Security contributions were made by your employer and thus not taxed.[http://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/p915.pdf IRS Publication 915, Social Security and Equivalent Railroad Retirement Benefits]) There are two relevant base amounts; unlike most income limits in the tax code, they are not adjusted for inflation. The lower base is $25,000 if you are single, $32,000 if married filing jointly. The upper base is $34,000 if you are single, $44,000 if married filing jointly. If your relevant income is below the lower base, none of your benefits are taxable. For every $1 of relevant income between the lower and upper bases, 50 cents of your Social Security benefits become taxable, up to 50% of your total benefits. For every $1 of relevant income above the upper bases, 85 cents of your Social Security benefits become taxable, up to a total taxable amount of 85% of your benefits. ==Examples== {{Notice|See: [[Tools_and_calculators#Personal_finance_toolbox |Personal finance toolbox]] - the tool used to generate charts below - for your own situation.}} The examples below are based on tax numbers for 2025.Tax bracket is based on Taxable income from {{Cite web| title=IRS releases tax inflation adjustments for tax year 2026, including amendments from the One, Big, Beautiful Bill|url=https://www.irs.gov/newsroom/irs-releases-tax-inflation-adjustments-for-tax-year-2026-including-amendments-from-the-one-big-beautiful-bill|access-date=November 27, 2025|website=Internal Revenue Service}} They illustrate how tax brackets and Social Security taxation interact, creating a 22.2% marginal tax rate for most taxpayers in the 12% tax bracket, and a 40.7% marginal tax rate (or slightly higher in the phase-out of the senior deduction) for * Single taxpayers 65 and older with SS benefits above $33,959; at that SS, the marginal tax rate begins at ordinary income of $45,685; * Married taxpayers 65 and older with SS benefits above $82,488; at that SS, the marginal tax rate begins at ordinary income above $78,185. ===Single taxpayers=== If you are single and receive $36,000 in Social Security benefits: *None of your benefits are taxable if your other income is less than $7,000. *For every dollar between $7,000 and $16,000, an additional 50 cents becomes taxable (although the tax is zero in this whole range; taxpayers with lower benefits may owe tax) *For every dollar over $19,000, an additional 85 cents becomes taxable, up to a total other income of $46,706, which makes the maximum $30,600 taxable. The table below assumes that you take the 2026 standard deduction ($24,150 for a taxpayer over 65, phases out by 6% of adjusted gross income over $75,000 to create an effective 23.32% tax bracket) {|class="wikitable" style="text-align:right" |- !Non-SS Income!!Taxable SS!!Adjusted gross income!!Taxable income !Tax bracket!!Additional SS taxed for each $1 income !Marginal tax rate |- | 7,000|| 0||10,000|| 0|| 0%||0.50|| 0% |- |16,000|| 4,500||20,500|| 0|| 0%||0.85|| 0% |- |17,973|| 6,177||24,150|| 0||10%||0.85|| 18.5% |- |24,676||11,875||36,551|| 12,401||12%||0.85|| 22.2% |- |45,216||29,334||74,550|| 50,400||22%||0.85|| 40.7% |- |45,459||29,540||74,999|| 50,849||23.32%||0.85|| 43.14% |- |46,706||30,600||77,306|| 53,294||23.32%||0|| 23.32% |} In graphical form,[http://forum.mrmoneymustache.com/forum-information-faqs/case-study-spreadsheet-updates/ The MMM Case Study Spreadsheet], [http://forum.mrmoneymustache.com/index.php The Mr. Money Mustache Community], viewed Dec. 23, 2022. assuming the non-SS income comes from tIRA withdrawals,
[[File:SS single tax.png]]
===Married taxpayers=== If you are a married couple, receive $72,000 in Social Security benefits and no other income except as described below: *You are already in the 50% phase-in and $2000 of your benefits are taxable even with no other income (but the tax is zero) *For every dollar up to $8,000, an additional 50 cents becomes taxable. *For every dollar over $8,000, an additional 85 cents becomes taxable, up to a total other income of $72,941, which makes the maximum $61,200 taxable. The table below assumes that you take the 2026 standard deduction ($47,500 for a married couple over 65, phases out by 12% of adjusted gross income over $150,000 to create an effective 24.44% bracket but it is not reached in this example) {|class="wikitable" style="text-align:right" |- !Non-SS Income!!Taxable SS!!Adjusted gross income!!Taxable income !Tax bracket!!Additional SS taxed for each $1 income !Marginal tax rate |- | 0|| 2,000|| 2,000|| 0|| 0%||0.50|| 0% |- | 8,000|| 6,000|| 14,000|| 0|| 0%||0.85|| 0% |- |26,108||21,392|| 47,500|| 0||10%||0.85|| 18.5% |- |39,514||32,787|| 72,301|| 24,801||12%||0.85|| 22.2% |- |72,941||61,200|| 134,141|| 86,641||12%|| 0|| 12% |- |87,100||61,200|| 148,300||100,800||22%|| 0|| 22% |} In graphical form, assuming the non-SS income comes from tIRA withdrawals,
[[File:SS Married Tax.png]]
With very high benefits and qualified dividends or long-term capital gains, it is possible to have an even higher marginal tax rate. Here is an example of a married couple with $90,000 in Social Security and $20,000 in qualified dividends. The qualified dividends are not taxed until their taxable income reaches $98,900. But when that happens, each dollar of taxable income increases tax by 27 cents, as it is taxed at 12% and causes a dollar of qualified dividends to be taxed at 15% rather than 0%. This creates a marginal tax rate of 49.95%, increasing to 54.83% when they also hit the phase-out of the senior deduction, then decreasing back to 29.64% once the maximum 85% of Social security is taxed. {|class="wikitable" style="text-align:right" |- !Non-SS Income!!Taxable SS!!Adjusted gross income!!Taxable income !Adjusted tax bracket!!Additional SS taxed for each $1 income !Marginal tax rate |- | 0|| 6,850|| 6,850|| 0|| 0%||0.85|| 0% |- |21,973||25,527|| 47,500|| 0|| 0%||0.85|| 0% |- |32,784||34,716|| 67,500|| 20,000||10%||0.85|| 18.5% |- |46,189||46,111|| 93,300|| 44,800||12%||0.85|| 22.2% |- |75,342||70,967|| 146,399|| 98.899||27%||0.85|| 49.95% |- |77,378||72,621|| 149,999||102,499||29.64%||0.85|| 54.83% |- |81,941||76,500|| 158,440||111,447||29.64%|| 0|| 29.64% |} In graphical form, assuming the OI comes from taxable IRA withdrawals/conversions, and starting the marginal rate calculations at $0 withdrawn/converted:
[[File:SS Married marginal rates chart1.png|alt=]]
If you have already made a $48.7K taxable IRA withdrawal (converted to Roth or not) and are considering a larger amount for the year, the marginal rates for amounts between $48.7K and $70K are shown here: [[File:SS Married marginal rates chart2.png]] There is no 40.7% rate in either of the above situations because the example couple reaches the maximum taxable SS benefit amount well before reaching the 22% tax bracket. ==Heat map representation== Plotting marginal tax rates as a function of Social Security income (horizontal axis) and non-Social Security income (vertical access) gives the following "heat map" style plots. [[File:SSHeatMapSingle2023.png|thumb|right|Marginal Tax Rate vs. Social Security and non-Social Security Income, 2025 Single Filers]] [[File:SSHeatMapMFJ2023.png|thumb|right|Marginal Tax Rate vs. Social Security and non-Social Security Income, 2025 Married Joint Filers]] The central point on each plot above which 40.7% marginal rates become possible can be calculated directly the formulas that describe taxation of Social Security, described above. As of 2026, these values are: {| class="wikitable" |- ! Filing Status !! 22% Threshold !! Standard Deduction !! Social Security !! Other Income |- | Single || $50,400 || $24,150 || $33,959 || $45,685 |- | Married Joint || $100,800|| $47,500 || $82,488 || $78,185 |} Taxpayers earning less Social Security income than these values are possibly affected by the 22.2% bump. As a function of annual Social Security benefit (SS), the 22.2% bump begins and ends at the following levels of income from other sources: {| class="wikitable" |- ! Filing Status !! 22.2% Bump Begins !! 22.2% Bump Ends |- | Single || $34,000 - 0.5 * SS || $28,706 + 0.5 * SS |- | Married Joint || $56,054 - 0.2297 * SS || $36,941 + 0.5 * SS |} Taxpayers earning more Social Security income than the above values are possibly affected by the 40.7% bump. As a function of annual Social Security benefit (SS), the 40.7% bump begins and ends at the following levels of income from other sources: {| class="wikitable" |- ! Filing Status !! 40.7% Bump Begins !! 40.7% Bump Ends |- | Single || $53,486 - 0.2297 * SS || $28,706 + 0.5 * SS |- | Married Joint || $97,135 - 0.2297 * SS || $36,941 + 0.5 * SS |} See the [[Tax_analysis#Derivation_of_tax_rate_boundaries_for_Social_Security_taxation|Tax analysis]] page for a derivation of these formulas. ===Examples=== A single taxpayer receiving $36,000 of Social Security benefits would be possibly affected by the 40.7% bump because the amount is more than $33,959. The 40.7% bump begins at '''$45,217''' ($53,486 - 0.2297 * $36,000) and ends at '''$46,706''' ($28,706 + 0.5 * $360,000). These values agree with the above charts except for a $1 rounding difference. Married taxpayers receiving $72,000 of Social Security benefits would be possibly affected by the 22.2% bump, but not the 40.7% bump, because the amount is less than $82,488. The 22.2% bump begins at '''$39,516''' ($56,054 - 0.2297 * $72,000) and ends at '''$72,941''' ($36,941 + 0.5 * $72,000). These values also agree with the above charts except for a $2 rounding difference. ==State taxation== [[File:State ssc tax large.png|thumb|right|300px|Figure 1.]] While most states do not tax social security benefits (as of 2021, shaded blue in figure; along with gray shaded states which do not impose income tax; Missouri, Nebraska,[https://governor.nebraska.gov/press/governor-pillen-signs-historic-tax-cuts-package Governor Pillen Signs Historic Tax Cuts Package] North Dakota,[https://www.tax.nd.gov/news/tax-legislative-changes/updates-office-state-tax-commissioner-newsletters/income-tax-update Income Tax Update - Special Session 2021] and West Virginia have eliminated the tax since this figure), eleven states (shaded pink or light blue) do tax them. These states that tax benefits to the extent they are taxed at the federal level: [https://www.retirementliving.com/taxes-by-state Retirementliving.com taxes by state] *'''Minnesota''' *'''Rhode Island''' These states tax Social Security normally, but exempt all qualifying retirement income, including both Social Security and pensions, for retirees at a lower income level: *'''Colorado''' *'''Montana''' *'''Utah''' These states tax Social Security benefits only partially, or only at certain income levels: *'''Connecticut''': Allows taxpayers to totally exempt Social Security from state income tax if income is less than $75,000 single, $100,000 married; above that, only 25% of federally taxed Social Security is taxed in CT. *'''Kansas''': Exempts Social Security benefits from state taxation if federal adjusted income is less than $75,000. *'''New Mexico''' : Benefits are exempt for a taxpayer 65 years of age or older, with income up to $100,000 single, $150,000 married filing jointly. *'''Vermont''': Social Security is taxed only for income above $45,000 single, $60,000 married. ==Notes== {{Reflist|group="note"}} ==See also== *[[Tools and calculators#Social Security | Social Security Calculators on the Bogleheads' wiki]] - Calculators to estimate your potential benefit amounts using different retirement dates and levels of future earnings. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *IRS Publication 915, Social Security and Equivalent Railroad Retirement Benefits: [http://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/p915.pdf PDF] or [http://www.irs.gov/publications/p915 Online] *[https://www.prudential.com/wps/wcm/connect/86ae97da-2bf3-40a1-9727-d5f0c050328b/maximize-social-security-benefits.pdf?MOD=AJPERES&CVID=nkCVUtj Innovative Strategies to Help Maximize Social Security Benefits] James Mahaney, Vice President, Strategic Initiatives, Prudential {{Retirement planning}} {{Tax considerations}} [[Category:Tax considerations]] [[Category: Social Security]] [[Category:Pages requiring annual tax updates]]

page.title: Taxation as a US person living abroad

revision.comment: /* Foreign Earned Income Exclusion (FEIE) */ updated limits for 2026
revision.text:
{{US expat}}
'''{{PAGENAME}}''' involves special considerations for individual taxpayers. If you are a US citizen or resident alien, the rules for filing income, estate, and gift tax returns and paying estimated tax are generally the same whether you are in the United States or abroad. Your worldwide income is subject to US income tax, regardless of where you reside.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/individuals/international-taxpayers/us-citizens-and-resident-aliens-abroad| title=U.S. Citizens and Resident Aliens Abroad| publisher=IRS| accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref>
Among the tax issues confronting you are additional reporting requirements for foreign bank and investment accounts, along with a number of applicable exclusions, deductions, and tax credits. If you have a non-citizen spouse you face potential limitations on inheritance and gifting. If you renounce or relinquish citizenship, or abandon permanent residency, you may face additional special taxes.
==Definitions== ===US person=== For US tax purposes, US citizens and permanent residents (green card holders) living outside the US face the same filing requirements as US residents. Collectively, these are all 'US persons'.
If you hold a green card, you must formally surrender your status to free yourself from US tax filing requirements as a resident alien. The most common way to do this is to file Form I-407<ref name="i-407">{{cite web| url=https://www.uscis.gov/i-407| title=I-407, Record of Abandonment of Lawful Permanent Resident Status| publisher=USCIS| accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref> with USCIS, and then filing ''Form 8854, "Initial and Annual Expatriation Statement."'' with the IRS. See "[[#Expatriation tax for losing citizenship or permanent residency |Expatriation tax]]" below for further details.
:'''Warning''': If you are a green card holder, even living outside the US long enough that the card expires or that US immigration authorities consider it no longer valid for immigration ''does not change'' your tax and filing status for the IRS.
===Expatriate=== The IRS code defines "expatriate" as someone who has given up US citizenship or Permanent Resident (green card) status.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/individuals/international-taxpayers/frequently-asked-questions-about-international-individual-tax-matters| title=Frequently Asked Questions About International Individual Tax Matters| publisher=IRS| accessdate=May 11, 2021}}</ref> Take care not to confuse this with the more normal English meaning of the term "expatriate," which refers to a citizen of one country residing in another country, and is generally shortened to "expat."
For clarity, this article uses the terms "expatriate" and "expatriation" only in the specific IRS sense. It avoids the term "expat" and uses "US person living outside the US" or "US person living abroad" to mean US citizens and green card holders living in countries other than the US.
==Filing requirements== ===Form 1040=== If you are a US person living outside the US, you must still file tax returns with the IRS. You receive an automatic two month extension to the filing deadline.
===Report of foreign bank and financial accounts (FBAR)=== If the aggregate contents of ''all'' your financial accounts located outside the US exceeds $10,000 at any point in the year, you must file ''FinCEN Form 114, Report of Foreign Bank and Financial Accounts (FBAR)''<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.fincen.gov/report-foreign-bank-and-financial-accounts| title=FinCEN Form 114, Report of Foreign Bank and Financial Accounts| publisher=US Treasury| accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.fincen.gov/news/news-releases/fincen-introduces-new-form-authorizing-fbar-filing-spouses-and-third-parties| title=FinCEN Introduces New Form for Authorizing FBAR Filing by Spouses and Third Parties| publisher=US Treasury| accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref> (formerly ''Form TD F 90-22.1'') by April 15 of the following year, with automatic extension to October 15 for all filers.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.fincen.gov/news/news-releases/new-due-date-fbars-0| title=New Due Date for FBARs| publisher=US Treasury| accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref> This form goes to the Treasury Department, but '''not''' to the IRS — it goes to a different branch of the Treasury. As of 2013, you '''must''' file this form electronically; no other options are available. The BSA E-Filing System site<ref>{{cite web| url=https://bsaefiling.fincen.treas.gov/main.html| title=BSA E-Filing System| publisher=US Treasury| accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref> handles electronic filing.
:'''Warning''': For FinCEN Form 114 you must report not only accounts belonging to yourself but also any accounts over which you have signature authority, such as company or other organizational accounts.
===Statement of specified foreign financial assets (FATCA)===
''Form 8938, Statement of Specified Foreign Financial Assets'' (often referred to as the FATCA form),<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/forms-pubs/about-form-8938| title=Form 8938, Statement of Specified Foreign Financial Assets| publisher=IRS| accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref> is similar to the FBAR, and reports almost the same information, but you file this form with the IRS along with your tax return.<ref group="note">Details are in [https://www.irs.gov/businesses/corporations/fatca-information-for-individuals FATCA Information for Individuals], from the IRS.</ref>
The Form 8938 filing requirement does not replace or otherwise affect your obligation to file FinCEN Form 114 (FBAR,[[#Report of foreign bank and financial accounts (FBAR) | above]]). You have to file each form for which you meet the relevant reporting threshold. A comprehensive FAQ detailing requirements for each form can be found at the IRS: Comparison of Form 8938 and FBAR Requirements.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/Businesses/Comparison-of-Form-8938-and-FBAR-Requirements| title=Comparison of Form 8938 and FBAR Requirements| publisher=IRS| accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref>
==Foreign Earned Income Exclusion (FEIE)==
The IRS sums up the Foreign Earned Income Exclusion (FEIE):<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/individuals/international-taxpayers/foreign-earned-income-exclusion| title=Foreign Earned Income Exclusion| publisher=IRS| accessdate=April 22, 2023}}</ref> {{quotation|If you are a U.S. citizen or a resident alien of the United States and you live abroad, you are taxed on your worldwide income. However, you may qualify to exclude from income up to an amount of your foreign earnings that is adjusted annually for inflation ($107,600 for 2020, $108,700 for 2021, $112,000 for 2022, and $120,000 for 2023 [$126,500 for 2024, $130,000 for 2025, $132,900 for 2026]).|IRS on the Foreign Earned Income Exclusion}}
You use ''Form 2555, Foreign Earned Income''<ref name="Form 2555">{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/forms-pubs/about-form-2555| title=Form 2555, Foreign Earned Income| publisher=IRS| accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref> to figure your FEIE.
The FEIE only applies to ''earned'' income (wages and salary), not to passive income (rent, interest, [[dividend]]s, capital gains). Where the work was performed determines where the income is deemed to have been earned, NOT where the money comes from. For example, if you live and work abroad and are paid by a US employer, it is foreign earned income (with exceptions for some government employees). If you live abroad and work for a foreign employer, and they send you to the US on business, the US considers all wages earned while physically in the US as US-source income. Also, income earned in international airspace, international waters, Antarctica, and even outer space, are all treated as US-source income.
Tax treaties<ref name="Tax Treaties">{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/Individuals/International-Taxpayers/Tax-Treaties|title=Tax Treaties| publisher=IRS| accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref> may have the effect of returning the right of first taxation to a foreign government even for work performed in the US.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/individuals/international-taxpayers/foreign-tax-credit-special-issues| title=Foreign Tax Credit — Special Issues (IRS)| publisher=IRS| accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref> You may need to use a [[foreign tax credit]] for this case. For example, if you are a full-time resident of Japan, and your Japanese employer sends you to the US on a business trip, the US-Japan tax treaty<ref name="US-Japan Tax Treaty">{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/businesses/international-businesses/japan-tax-treaty-documents| title=US-Japan Tax Treaty Documents| publisher=IRS| accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref> specifies that the income you earned while in the US is to be treated as though you earned it in Japan. You cannot, however, exclude this income from US taxation using the FEIE. Instead, you need to pay whatever Japanese taxes are due on the income, and then use the Additional Foreign Tax Credit worksheet<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/publications/p514/ar02.html#en_US_2012_publink1000244962| title=Additional Foreign Tax Credit Worksheet| publisher=IRS| accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref> in the back of Pub. 514<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/publications/p514/index.html| title=IRS Pub. 514| publisher=IRS| accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref> to calculate the foreign tax credit that you can take against the US taxes levied on that same income.
==Foreign Tax Credit (FTC)== {{Main article|Foreign tax credit}}
You can take a Foreign Tax Credit (FTC) for foreign taxes paid on income that is not excluded using the FEIE. In some cases, where the foreign tax rate is high enough to more than cancel any US taxes due, it may be more advantageous to use only the FTC and forgo the FEIE — for example, to keep you eligible to make IRA contributions.<ref group="note">You claim the foreign tax credit by filing [https://www.irs.gov/forms-pubs/about-form-1116 Form 1116 Foreign Tax Credit].</ref>
There are significant limitations on your ability to switch back and forth between using the FTC and the FEIE. Regarding the FEIE, the IRS states:<ref name="Instructions 2555">{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/instructions/i2555/ch01.html#d0e181| title=Instructions for Form 2555| publisher=IRS| accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref> {{quotation|Once you choose to claim an exclusion, that choice remains in effect for that year and all future years unless it is revoked. To revoke your choice, you must attach a statement to your return for the first year you do not wish to claim the exclusion(s). If you revoke your choice, you cannot claim the exclusion(s) for your next 5 tax years without the approval of the Internal Revenue Service. See Pub. 54 for more information."|IRS on the Foreign Earned Income Exclusion}}
==Foreign housing exclusion or deduction== You can take an exclusion or deduction for certain foreign housing-related expenses, to the extent that they exceed a certain threshold ($19,200/year in 2022). There is a cap on the amount that you can claim that varies by location.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/instructions/i2555#limitonhousingexpensesworksheetline-eae47989| title=Instructions for Form 2555, Limits on Housing Expenses| publisher=IRS| accessdate=November 14, 2023}}</ref> You use ''Form 2555, Foreign Earned Income''<ref name="Form 2555"/> to figure the exclusion or deduction.
The IRS describes what expenses are eligible:<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/instructions/i2555#limitonhousingexpensesworksheetline-eae47989| title=Instructions for Form 2555, Limits on Housing Expenses| publisher=IRS| accessdate=November 14, 2023}}</ref> {{quotation|Line 28. Enter the total reasonable expenses paid or incurred during the tax year by you, or on your behalf, for your foreign housing and the housing of your spouse and dependents if they lived with you. You can also include the reasonable expenses of a second foreign household (defined later). Housing expenses are considered reasonable to the extent they are not lavish or extravagant under the circumstances.
Housing expenses include rent, utilities (other than telephone charges), real and personal property insurance, nonrefundable fees paid to obtain a lease, rental of furniture and accessories, residential parking, and household repairs. You can also include the fair rental value of housing provided by, or on behalf of, your employer if you have not excluded it on line 25.
Do not include deductible interest and taxes, any amount deductible by a tenant-stockholder in connection with cooperative housing, the cost of buying or improving a house, principal payments on a mortgage, or depreciation on the house. Also, do not include the cost of domestic labor, pay television, or the cost of buying furniture or accessories.|IRS Form 2555 instructions}}
For further details, see the instructions to Form 2555.<ref name="Instructions 2555"/>
==Living in a US territory outside of the USA== US territories and possessions include American Samoa, Guam, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, the US Virgin Islands, and Puerto Rico.
The IRS notes:<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/Individuals/International-Taxpayers/Individuals-Living-or-Working-in-US-Possessions| title=Individuals Living or Working in U.S. Territories / Possessions| publisher=IRS| accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref> {{quotation|American Samoa, Guam, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, the U.S. Virgin Islands, and Puerto Rico have their own independent tax departments.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/publications/p570/ch03.html| title=Filing Information for Individuals in Certain U.S. Possessions| publisher=IRS| accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref> If you have income from one of these US territories, you may have to file a US tax return only, a territory tax return only, or both returns. This generally depends on whether you are considered a resident of one of the US territories. In some cases, you may have to file a US return, but be able to exclude income earned in a territory from US tax. Filing requirements for specific US territories are explained in Publication 570.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/publications/p570/index.html| title=Publication 570, Tax Guide for Individuals With Income From U.S. Possessions| publisher=IRS| accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref>|IRS}}
==Non-citizen spouses== ===Choosing a filing status=== If your spouse is a non-resident alien, and you wish to file as Married Filing Jointly, you will need to choose to treat your spouse as a US resident for tax purposes as noted in Publication 54:<ref name="Publication 54: Nonresident Alien Spouse Treated as a Resident">{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/publications/p54#idm140719117359312| title=Publication 54: Tax Guide for U.S. Citizens and Resident Aliens Abroad| publisher=IRS| accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref> {{quotation|If, at the end of your tax year, you are married and one spouse is a U.S. citizen or a resident alien and the other is a nonresident alien, you can choose to treat the nonresident as a U.S. resident. This includes situations in which one of you is a nonresident alien at the beginning of the tax year and a resident alien at the end of the year and the other is a nonresident alien at the end of the year.
If you make this choice, the following two rules apply.
* You and your spouse are treated, for income tax purposes, as residents for all tax years that the choice is in effect. * You must file a joint income tax return for the year you make the choice.
This means that neither of you can claim under any tax treaty not to be a US resident for a tax year for which the choice is in effect.
You can file joint or separate returns in years after the year in which you make the choice.|IRS Publication 54}}
Once you make this election, it continues for all subsequent years. If you revoke it, you generally cannot ever choose it again.
:'''Warning''': Choosing to treat a nonresident alien spouse as a US resident creates US reporting requirements for all of that spouse's income and assets.
Publication 54 also notes: {{quotation|If you do not choose to treat your nonresident alien spouse as a U.S. resident, you may be able to use head of household filing status. To use this status, you must pay more than half the cost of maintaining a household for certain dependents or relatives other than your nonresident alien spouse. For more information, see Publication 501.|IRS Publication 54}}
For further details, see Publications 54<ref name="Publication 54: Nonresident Alien Spouse Treated as a Resident"/> and 501.<ref name="Publication 501: Head of Household">{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/publications/p501| title=Publication 501: Head of Household| publisher=IRS| accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref>
===Special conditions on spousal inheritance and gift taxes=== Nolo provides a short summary of inheritance and gift tax issues with a non-US citizen spouse:<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.nolo.com/legal-encyclopedia/estate-planning-when-you-re-married-noncitizen.html| title=Estate Planning When You’re Married to a Noncitizen| publisher=Nolo| accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref> {{quotation|'''Assets Left at Death'''
Assets left to a surviving spouse are not subject to federal estate tax, no matter how much they are worth, provided that the surviving spouse is a U.S. citizen. This rule is called the unlimited marital deduction. It is in addition to the individual exemption (currently $11.2 million) that everyone gets.
The marital deduction, however, does not apply when the spouse who inherits isn’t a U.S. citizen, even if the spouse is a permanent U.S. resident. The federal government doesn’t want someone who isn’t a citizen to inherit a large amount of money, pay no estate tax, and then leave the country to return to his or her native land.
Still, keep in mind you can leave assets worth up to the exempt amount (again, $11.2 million for deaths in 2018) to anyone, including your non-citizen spouse, without owing any federal estate tax. And if the non-citizen spouse dies first, assets left to the spouse who is a U.S. citizen do qualify for the unlimited marital deduction.<ref group="note">There are two common strategies employed to allow a non-citizen spouse to receive the unlimited marital deduction. # Get citizenship by the time the estate tax return is due. # A non-citizen spouse can inherit free of estate tax through the use a special trust, called a "qualified domestic trust" or QDOT. Property is placed in the trust, instead of directly to your spouse. Your spouse is the beneficiary of the trust; there can’t be any other beneficiaries while your spouse is alive. Your spouse receives income that the trust property generates; these amounts are not subject to estate tax. The trust must be established prior to the filing of the estate tax return. The trustee of the trust must be a US citizen or US corporation. See [https://www.nolo.com/legal-encyclopedia/using-qdots-plan-noncitizen-spouses.html A Qualified Domestic Trust (QDOT)], nolo.com. A QDOT requires expert professional guidance. It is important to realise that a QDOT does not avoid US estate tax, but only defers it until withdrawals of principal or the death of the surviving spouse.</ref>
'''Gifts Given During Life'''
If your spouse is a citizen, any gifts you give to him or her during your life are free of federal gift tax. If your spouse is not a U.S. citizen, however, the special tax-free treatment for spouses is limited to $152,000 a year (2018). This amount is indexed for inflation. That’s in addition to the $11.2 million you can give away or leave to anyone without owing federal gift/estate tax.|NOLO}}
These problems apply not only to US persons abroad, but to any US person who is married to a non-US citizen.
=== Establishing permanent residency in US===
It is possible for the foreign spouse (or other immediate relative) of a US citizen to apply for US permanent residency while still outside the US. According to the US Citizenship and Immigration Services:<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.uscis.gov/green-card/green-card-through-family/green-card-immediate-relative-us-citizen| title=Green Card for an Immediate Relative of a U.S. Citizen| publisher=USCIS| accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref> {{quotation|If you are currently outside the United States and are an immediate relative of a U.S. citizen, you can become a permanent resident through consular processing. Consular processing is when USCIS works with the Department of State to issue a visa on an approved Form I-130 petition when a visa is available. You may then travel on the visa and will officially become a permanent resident when admitted at a U.S. port of entry.|USCIS}}
For details, see the USCIS "Consular Processing" page.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.uscis.gov/green-card/green-card-processes-and-procedures/consular-processing| title=Consular Processing| publisher=USCIS| accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref>
==Expatriation tax for losing citizenship or permanent residency== ===Loss of status=== ====US Citizens==== The two primary ways to lose US citizenship are: * '''Relinquishing US citizenship:''' If you take the citizenship of another country with the intent of relinquishing US citizenship, you are considered to have "relinquished" US citizenship. You still have to notify your local US embassy in person for the loss to be recognized by the US government, however. On November 9, 2015, the consular processing fee for relinquishment rose from zero to $2,350.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2015/09/08/2015-22054/schedule-of-fees-for-consular-services-department-of-state-and-overseas-embassies-and| title=Schedule of Fees for Consular Services, Department of State and Overseas Embassies and Consulates-Passport and Citizenship Services Fee Changes| date=September 8, 2015| publisher=Federal Register| accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref> * '''Renouncing US citizenship:''' You can also "renounce" US citizenship, which requires you to take an oath of renunciation at a US embassy or consulate. This costs a $2,350 processing fee as of September 12, 2014,<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2014/08/28/2014-20516/schedule-of-fees-for-consular-services-department-of-state-and-overseas-embassies-and| title=Schedule of Fees for Consular Services, Department of State and Overseas Embassies and Consulates-Visa and Citizenship Services Fee Changes| date=August 28, 2014| publisher=Federal Register| accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref> and potentially subjects you to application of the [[wikipedia:Reed_Amendment_(immigration)|Reed Amendment]].<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/8/1182#a_10_E| title=Reed Amendment| publisher=Cornell Law School| accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref>
For tax purposes, relinquishment and renunciation are identical, with your tax filing obligation continuing up until the date of the appointment at the embassy or consulate. For other purposes (such as transmitting US citizenship to your children), your effective date of loss of citizenship is the date of the relinquishing act (such as acquiring another citizenship with intent to relinquish US citizenship), or if renouncing, the date you take the renunciation oath at the embassy or consulate.
:'''Warning''': Even if you take another citizenship intending to relinquish, if you then travel on your US passport, vote in a US election, or do anything else that indicates that you still consider yourself a US citizen after the presumed expatriating act, you will be deemed not to have relinquished after all, at which point renouncing may become the only recognized way for you to lose US citizenship.
====Green card holders==== The elective ways to lose a US green card are: * '''Abandoning US permanent residency:''' This is similar to relinquishing US citizenship. You need to file ''Form I-407, Abandonment of Lawful Permanent Resident Status''.<ref name="i-407" /> * '''Claiming US tax treaty benefits:''' A long-term permanent resident claiming treatment as a resident of another country and not waiving tax treaty treatment for that country is deemed to have lost permanent resident status.<ref name="expatriation_tax">{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/Individuals/International-Taxpayers/Expatriation-Tax| title=Expatriation Tax| publisher=IRS| accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref>
The first of these is the cleanest, and by far the most common. Prior to July 1, 2019, you could file Form I-407 with the USCIS field office in the local US embassy. After this date, you have to file this form directly with the USCIS in Vermont,<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.uscis.gov/news/alerts/uscis-will-no-longer-accept-i-407-at-international-field-offices| title=USCIS Will No Longer Accept I-407 at International Field Offices| publisher=USCIS| accessdate=November 1, 2020}}</ref> although a rare exception may be possible. The estimated processing time is 60 days, so you need to take this into account in any planning.
:'''Warning''': If you hold a green card you must formally surrender your status to free yourself from US tax filing requirements as a resident alien. Allowing the physical card to expire so that US immigration authorities consider it no longer valid for immigration ''does not change'' your tax and filing status for the IRS.
===Tax consequences=== In either case of losing citizenship, or in the case of losing permanent residency if you have been a lawful permanent resident of the US in at least eight of the past fifteen years, the tax implications are similar. You need to file ''IRS Form 8854, Initial and Annual Expatriation Statement'',<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/forms-pubs/about-form-8854| title=IRS Form 8854 Initial and Annual Expatriation Statement| publisher=IRS| accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref> and potentially pay exit taxes based on a deemed disposition of assets and a deemed ''immediate distribution of all pension and retirement savings''.
The cases described above are the most common ones, but there are many special cases and exceptions, and different rules apply for those who lost citizenship or residency in previous years. For details, see ''Instructions for Form 8854'',<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/instructions/i8854/ar01.html#d0e29| title=Instructions for Form 8854| publisher=IRS| accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref> and the IRS discussion of the expatriation tax.<ref name="expatriation_tax" />
This is also an area where the laws have changed frequently in recent years, and the tax traps here are numerous and severe, so be ''very'' careful if you plan on taking any of the above steps.
==Investing as a US person living abroad==
===Investing from within the US=== ====401(k) and Roth 401(k) contributions==== If you have access to [[401(k)]] or Roth 401(k) plans, it may be worth thinking about what order to make contributions to what kind of plan. For example, it may make sense to make pre-tax contributions to a 401(k) until you no longer have taxable income (with the remainder being untaxed due to application of reductions such as the FEIE, the Standard Deduction, and the Personal Exemption), and make post-tax contributions with any amounts above that.
====IRA and Roth IRA contributions==== If you use the FEIE, you cannot use any of the excluded income to contribute to an [[Roth IRA|IRA]]. You can contribute if you have earned income above the FEIE limit, and below the IRA contribution cutoff. You can also contribute using earned income that is not excludable (for example, wages you earn during a business trip to the US, which are considered US-source income even if paid by a non-US employer).<ref group="note"> In the case of spousal IRAs, your spouse's non-excluded income can be used to found a spousal IRA. Pub 590 is quite clear on this question: # Taxable compensation for IRA contribution purposes does not include income excluded under the FEIE or housing exclusions, but if one spouse has taxable compensation over this exclusion, the excess income can fund an IRA contribution. # A spousal contribution can be made for the lower earning spouse using income from the higher earner. The spouse whose taxable compensation exceeds the FEIE can therefore provide this excess taxable comp for the other lower earning spouse. In other words, the excess taxable comp of the higher earning spouse does not have to be applied to the remaining FEIE of the lower earning spouse. </ref >
You do not have to use the FEIE, but if you do use the FEIE, you have to use all of it, and exclude all income that is excludable up to the exclusion limit. It is NOT possible to partially exclude eligible earned income and leave some un-excluded for IRA contributions.
===Investing locally (from outside the US)=== If you invest where you live, you need to be aware of several issues and hindrances caused by US tax rules.
====Passive foreign investment company (PFIC)==== {{Main article|Passive foreign investment company}}
[[Mutual fund]]s, [[Exchange-traded funds|exchange-traded fund]]s (ETFs), [[Real estate investment trust |real estate investment trust]]s (REITs) and other collective investment vehicles, if they are not registered with the US Securities Exchange Commission (SEC), are classified under US tax law as Passive Foreign Investment Companies, or PFICs. The taxation on these under US law is ''extremely'' unfavorable, and requires you to file ''Form 8621, Information Return by a Shareholder of a Passive Foreign Investment Company or Qualified Electing Fund''<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/forms-pubs/about-form-8621| title=Form 8621, Information Return by a Shareholder of a Passive Foreign Investment Company or Qualified Electing Fund| publisher=IRS| accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref> with your tax return, which can be an extremely time consuming task.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/instructions/i8621/ar02.html#d0e1437| title=IRS Form 8621 instructions: Disclosure, Privacy Act, and Paperwork Reduction Act Notice| publisher=IRS| accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref>
In general, to avoid PFIC issues, you can only invest through SEC-registered investment vehicles (which may in turn incur tax problems with the local tax authorities), or otherwise through individual [[Stock basics|stocks]] and [[Bond basics|bonds]].
For a discussion of how to invest using individual stocks, see the Wiki page on [[Passively managing individual stocks|passively managing individual stocks]].
If you live in the UK, you need to use HMRC 'reporting funds' to avoid the UK's higher tax rates for gains in offshore (to the UK) funds. A selection of US domiciled ETFs are HMRC reporting funds. For more, see the Wiki page on [[US domiciled ETFs that are UK HMRC reporting funds]].
====Forms W-9 and W-8BEN==== If, as a US person, you open a financial account outside the US that deals with US securities (brokerage dealing in US stocks and ETFs, for example), you account provider should give you a Form W-9<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/forms-pubs/about-form-w-9| title=Form W-9, Request for Taxpayer Identification Number (TIN) and Certification| publisher=IRS| accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref> to fill out. This form identifies owners of US securities who are US persons, and tells your brokerage NOT to withhold US taxes from US-source distributions, since you will declare them on your US tax return separately.
If you are a US person, you should NOT fill out a Form W-8BEN.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/forms-pubs/about-form-w-8-ben| title=Form W-8BEN, Certificate of Foreign Status of Beneficial Owner for United States Tax Withholding| publisher=IRS| accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref> This form is for non-resident aliens, and will typically result in US taxes being automatically withheld on distributions. (If you do find yourself subject to automatic withholding for some reason, this does not relieve you of the requirement to report the distributions on your US taxes, it just makes the job more complicated.)
====US-based brokerages====
Because of FATCA, most non-US brokerages (and many US based ones) now refuse access to US persons living outside the US. However, [[Interactive Brokers]] welcome this client group.<ref group="note">For more, see: [https://www.interactivebrokers.com/ Interactive Brokers home page].</ref>
Several major US brokerages do not allow investors to open accounts from outside the US. Vanguard is one example.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://personal.vanguard.com/us/LiteratureRequest?FW_Activity=FindLiteratureActivity&FW_Event=specialnotice| title=Special notice to non-U.S. investors| publisher=Vanguard| accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref> Another example is Schwab, which no longer offers accounts to residents of Japan.<ref>[[Investing from Japan for US citizens and US permanent residents#US-based brokerage|Investing from Japan for US citizens and US permanent residents § US-based brokerage]]</ref><ref group="note">Search the forum for suggested alternative brokerages and workrounds: [https://www.google.com/search?sitesearch=bogleheads.org&q=Vanguard+ex-pat+site:bogleheads.org Vanguard ex-pat site:bogleheads.org - Google Search]</ref>
====EU and UK residents and PRIIPs====
In 2018, the European [https://finance.ec.europa.eu/consumer-finance-and-payments/retail-financial-services/key-information-documents-packaged-retail-and-insurance-based-investment-products-priips_en PRIIPs] (''Packaged Retail and Insurance-based Investment Products'') regulation became effective. As a result it is now difficult or even impossible for EU residents to purchase US domiciled funds directly (although indirect purchases potentially remain possible<ref group=note>Forum member "finrod_2002" provides details of how an investor might use options trades to work around PRIIPs restrictions, in {{forum post|p=4386305|title=Re: European, dutch investor here: Is investing in VTI and VXUS still a good choice?|date=17 Feb 2019}}, viewed 28 Oct 2019.</ref>). Shares purchased before the regulation came into effect can be kept and sold, but EU residents can generally no longer buy new shares of these funds or ETFs.
The UK left the EU in January 2020, but created its own 'UK PRIIPs' regime that is fully aligned with the EU PRIIPs, so PRIIPs restrictions continue to apply in the UK.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/draft-packaged-retail-and-insurance-based-investment-products-amendment-eu-exit-regulations-2019/packaged-retail-and-insurance-based-investment-products-amendment-eu-exit-regulations-2019-explanatory-information| title=Packaged Retail and Insurance-based Investment Products (Amendment) (EU Exit)| publisher=GOV.UK| accessdate=February 1, 2020}} Regulations 2019: explanatory information</ref>
==Cross-border taxation== In general, other countries do not recognize the tax-advantaged status of US accounts such as IRAs, 401(k)s, Coverdell ESAs, and 529 plans. And symmetrically, the US generally does not recognize other countries' tax-advantaged accounts either.
There are some limited exceptions, depending on tax treaty.<ref name="Tax Treaties"/> For example, the US-Canada tax treaty<ref name="US-Canada Tax Treaty">{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/businesses/international-businesses/canada-tax-treaty-documents| title=US-Canada Tax Treaty Documents| publisher=IRS| accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.canada.ca/en/department-finance/programs/tax-policy/tax-treaties/country/united-states-america-convention-consolidated-1980-1983-1984-1995-1997-2007.html| title=Convention Between Canada and the United States of America With Respect to Taxes on Income and on Capital| publisher=Government of Canada| accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref> provides for cross-recognition of some (but not all) tax advantaged accounts in either country, as does the US-UK treaty.<ref name="US-UK Tax Treaty">{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/businesses/international-businesses/united-kingdom-uk-tax-treaty-documents| title=US-UK UK Tax Treaty Documents| publisher=IRS| accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref> But the US-Japan treaty,<ref name="US-Japan Tax Treaty"/> for example, has no such provisions, so Japan will treat a Roth IRA as just another taxable account, and the US will do the same with a NISA (Japan's equivalent to a Roth IRA).
===Canadian tax advantaged accounts=== Canadian registered retirement savings plans (RRSPs) and registered retirement income funds (RRIFs) held by US citizens can receive tax exempt status.<ref name="collins">{{cite web| url=https://www.bakertilly.ca/en/btc/publications/u.s.-tax-treatment-of-certain-canadian-tax-deferred-accounts| title=U.S. Tax Treatment of Certain Canadian Tax-Deferred Accounts| publisher=Baker Tilly| accessdate=July 12, 2024}}</ref><ref group="note">In 2014, the IRS eliminated the requirement to report RRSPs on ''Form 8891, U.S. Information Return for Beneficiaries of Certain Canadian Registered Retirement Plans''. (Ref: [https://www.irs.gov/newsroom/irs-simplifies-procedures-for-favorable-tax-treatment-on-canadian-retirement-plans-and-annual-reporting-requirements IRS Simplifies Procedures for Favorable Tax Treatment on Canadian Retirement Plans and Annual Reporting Requirements], Oct. 7, 2014). However, [https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-drop/rp-14-55.pdf Revenue Procedure 2014-55] Sections 5, 6, and 7 suggest this Form be filed to report on [https://www.irs.gov/forms-pubs/about-form-8938 Form 8938] that they have filed Form 8891 with respect to an RRSP or RRIF.</ref>
Registered education savings plans (RESPs) and Tax-Free Savings Accounts (TFSAs) cannot receive tax exempt status and may be subject to additional tax filings.<ref name="collins" />
