{{US|reason=irrelevant}}
'''{{PAGENAME}}''', also known as '''FICA''' (Federal Insurance Contributions Act)<ref>[https://www.ssa.gov/thirdparty/materials/pdfs/educators/What-is-FICA-Infographic-EN-05-10297.pdf What is FICA?], Social Security Administration (SSA)</ref> or '''FICA tax''', is a tax in the United States against [[Earned income|earned income]].
It has three components: [[Social Security]] tax on earned income up to the Social Security Wage Base ($176,100 in 2025); [[Medicare]] tax on all earned income; and the Additional Medicare Tax on earned income above $200,000 for single taxpayers or $250,000 for married couples (implemented by the [[wikipedia:Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act|Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act]] (ACA)).
The employee and employer share the Social Security tax and Medicare tax. Each pays half the tax, and the employer must withhold the employee's half of these two taxes from the employee's paychecks.
The employee pays any Additional Medicare Tax entirely, although employers are required to withhold the Additional Medicare Tax on all wages over $200,000, without regard to the employee's filing status.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/businesses/small-businesses-self-employed/questions-and-answers-for-the-additional-medicare-tax| title=Additional Medicare Tax Withholding| publisher=IRS| access-date=October 1, 2023}}</ref>
==Description==
The following table summarizes payroll taxes:
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Payroll tax !! Tax rate !! Income limits<ref>[https://www.irs.gov/taxtopics/tc751 Topic No. 751 Social Security and Medicare Withholding Rates], Internal Revenue Service.</ref> |- | Employee half of Social Security tax || 6.2% || Up to Social Security Wage Base ($184,500 as of 2026<ref>https://www.ssa.gov/oact/cola/cbb.html</ref>) for each individual |- | Employer half of Social Security tax || 6.2% || Up to Social Security Wage Base ($184.500 as of 2026) for each individual |- | Employee half of Medicare tax || 1.45% || All earned income |- | Employer half of Medicare tax || 1.45% || All earned income |- | Additional Medicare Tax || 0.9% || Earned income above $200,000 for single filers, or $250,000 for married joint filers |}
Details: * Payroll taxes are assessed against [[Earned income|earned income]] (also called '''wages''') only. Investment income (interest, dividends, and so on ), real estate income reported on [https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/f1040se.pdf IRS Schedule E], and income from Partnerships or S Corporations reported on [https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/f1065sk1.pdf IRS Schedule K-1 (Form 1065)] or [https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/f1120ssk.pdf IRS Schedule K-1 (Form 1120S)], is not assessed payroll tax. * Contributions to Traditional [[401(k)|401(k)'s]] and [[Traditional IRA|IRAs]] are ''not'' payroll tax-deductible, only income tax-deductible. * Contributions to [[Payroll - cafeteria plan deductions|employer cafeteria plans]], such as [[Health savings account|Health Savings Accounts (HSAs)]] and health insurance ''are'' payroll tax-deductible. The same type of contribution made outside those plans (e.g., directly to the HSA provider, or premiums for non-employer-provided health insurance) are ''not'' payroll tax-deductible. * Employers are required to withhold the employee's half of Social Security and Medicare tax from their paychecks. * Employers are also required to withhold the Additional Medicare Tax on all wages over $200,000 per year, regardless of the employee's filing status. * Self-employed sole proprietors<ref>[https://www.irs.gov/businesses/small-businesses-self-employed/sole-proprietorships IRS information on Sole Proprietorships], IRS</ref> are required to pay both halves of the payroll tax, calculated on [https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/f1040sse.pdf IRS Schedule SE (Form 1040)]. On the Schedule SE, net business profits are scaled down by a factor of 92.35%, so that the sole proprietorship gets to deduct the employer half of payroll taxes, similar to a corporation. * S Corporation owners are also required to pay both halves of the payroll tax, although they have the option to split compensation between wages and dividends, within certain restrictions, potentially reducing payroll tax (see [[#Avoiding payroll tax|below]]). * The Social Security Wage Base is adjusted annually by the Social Security Administration. Over the last several years, the figure has been increased by 3-4%/year, except for a 9.0% increase in 2023 due to high inflation. * The income thresholds for the Additional Medicare Tax ($200,000 for single filers and $250,000 for married joint filers) are not indexed for inflation.
==Exemptions from paying payroll tax==
Generally, you are not allowed to "opt out" of paying payroll taxes, even if you are willing to forgo future Social Security and Medicare benefits. However, certain types of jobs are exempt from payroll taxes, such as:
* Children under age 18 employed by their parents through a sole proprietorship or partnership, but not a corporation<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/businesses/small-businesses-self-employed/family-help| title=Family Help| publisher=IRS| access-date=October 1, 2023}}</ref> * Certain international workers within the United States, such as nonresident alien employees of foreign governments, students, and employees of international organizations.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/individuals/international-taxpayers/foreign-student-liability-for-social-security-and-medicare-taxes| title=Foreign Student Liability for Social Security and Medicare Taxes| publisher=IRS| access-date=October 1, 2023}}</ref> * Full-time students employed by their university * Members of certain exempt religious organizations<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/charities-non-profits/churches-religious-organizations/elective-fica-exemption-churches-and-church-controlled-organizations| title=Elective FICA Exemption Churches and Church Controlled Organizations| publisher=IRS| access-date=October 1, 2023}}</ref>
You must still pay Social Security tax even if you accumulate 35 years of earnings at or above the Social Security Wage Base.
==Recovering excess payroll tax==
If you are an employee and you work two or more jobs in a given year (either serially or concurrently), your employers must withhold Social Security tax from each paycheck. If your total wages are more than the Social Security Wage Base (SSWB, $184,500 in 2026), then you will have excess Social Security tax withheld. You can recover the excess Social Security tax. Enter claims for credit onto [https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/f1040s3.pdf IRS Form 1040 Schedule 3], on Line 11 of your federal income tax return. You can either apply the credit to income tax you owe, or have it returned as part of your tax refund. (Since this is treated as an income tax payment, you can get the credit back during the year by filing a Form W-4 to decrease withholding).
If your employer withholds excess Social Security in error, you should seek a refund from your employer.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/taxtopics/tc608| title=Tax Topic 608 - Excess Social Security and RRTA Tax Withheld| publisher=IRS| access-date=October 1, 2023}}</ref> If this is not successful, you can request a refund on [https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/f843.pdf IRS Form 843].
While employees are entitled to a refund for excess Social Security tax, ''employers'' are generally not entitled to a refund for their half of Social Security tax payments if the employee worked another job and overpaid. This affects business owners, and can have a particularly large impact on taxpayers who own their own business through a Corporation, and also work a second job as an employee.
The Corporation is required to pay the employer side of the Social Security tax up to the SSWB, even if the owner knows that some of this tax is on wages over the SSWB. This issue does not affect Sole Proprietors who work a second job as an employee, because [https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/f1040sse.pdf IRS Schedule SE (Form 1040)] corrects for Social Security tax paid from other employment.
Because the Medicare tax is assessed on all earned income, working for multiple employers does not create excess Medicare tax. However, the Additional Medicare Tax can create situations of under- or over-withholding. Employers must withhold Additional Medicare Tax on employee wages above $200,000, regardless of the employee's filing status.
For example, a married employee who earns $250,000 of wages, and whose spouse does not work, will have $450 (($250,000 - $200,000) * 0.9%) of Additional Medicare Tax withheld, even though their actual Additional Medicare Tax due is $0. Conversely, a married couple who each earn $200,000 of wages will owe $1,350 (($400,000 - $250,000) * 0.9%) of Additional Medicare Tax, even though none will be withheld.
In both cases, [https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/f8959.pdf IRS Form 8959] corrects this on their federal return. The IRS requires this form for all federal tax returns subject to the Additional Medicare Tax.
==Avoiding payroll tax==
For most taxpayers, there are no legal ways to avoid payroll taxes. However, owners of S Corporations may decide to split their compensation partly as wages and partly as dividends from the business,<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.kitces.com/blog/s-corporation-to-reduce-self-employment-taxes-and-social-security-fica/| title= Kitces - How An S Corporation Can Reduce FICA Self-Employment Taxes| publisher=Kitces| date=December 28, 2016| access-date=October 1, 2023}}</ref> reducing payroll taxes because they are not assessed on the dividends. This split is subject to the IRS requirement for "reasonable compensation."<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/businesses/small-businesses-self-employed/paying-yourself#7| title=Small Businesses - Self-employed| publisher=IRS| access-date=October 1, 2023}}</ref>
Even if a business owner is legally entitled to pay lower payroll taxes, there may be compelling reasons not to, such as the cost of becoming and remaining incorporated (compared to operating as a Sole Proprietor), lower employer contributions to a [[Solo 401(k) plan|Solo 401(k)]], and a potentially desirable [[Social Security as an investment|rate of return on Social Security tax paid]].
You can also avoid payroll tax when contributing to a [[Health savings account|Health Savings Account]] through an employer payroll deduction. If the [[Social Security as an investment|investment characteristics of Social Security tax]] (for example, rate of return) are desirable, you can make the payment directly to the HSA custodian.

US citizens and US permanent residents (green card holders) living in the UK can hold the funds listed below without running into problems with the US's harsh [[Passive foreign investment company]] (PFIC) tax regime, and also without running into higher UK tax because they hold HMRC non-reporting funds. The information in this article is specific to ''US citizens and US permanent residents who are UK residents''. ==Introduction== If you are a US citizen or US permanent resident (green card holder) living in the UK, then because of the way the US's citizenship-based taxation and harsh [[Passive foreign investment company]] (PFIC) tax regime intersect, you cannot use the normal range of [[wikipedia:Undertakings_for_Collective_Investment_in_Transferable_Securities_Directive_2009|UCITS]] funds and ETFs offered to other UK and EU residents. For you, holding US domiciled funds or ETFs is one of very few viable routes to index investing. However, the UK also has rules that discourage some "offshore" fund holdings. You would pay tax on gains in a non-UCITS fund or ETF that lacks HMRC ''reporting status'' at higher income rates, instead of lower and more beneficial capital gains rates. Many US domiciled funds and ETFs will not have HMRC reporting status. However, some US domiciled ETFs - including most Vanguard and Dimensional ETFs - are HMRC reporting funds. This means that you can invest through these ETFs without running into either country's unpleasant tax regime for "offshore" funds. ==US domiciled ETFs with HMRC reporting status== The following tablesThese tables are built using a script to extract data from HMRC's reporting funds spreadsheet. You can find the details for this in the [[Talk:{{PAGENAME}}|discussion page]] associated with this page. show a selection of US domiciled ETFs that you can safely use in taxable accounts. These are also safe to use in a UK [[UK Individual Savings Accounts|Individual Savings Account]] (ISA), although for you the ISA wrapper only provides protection from UK taxes, not from any US taxes. The US will tax your ISA gains annually as if it is a normal taxable account. The tables show data from HMRC's [https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/offshore-funds-list-of-reporting-funds approved offshore reporting funds] list, as of 10 November 2025. This list shows funds by [[wikipedia:CUSIP|CUSIP]]. The mapping from CUSIP to fund exchange ticker uses data from [https://www.openfigi.com/ OpenFIGI], as of 10 November 2025. If you are going to rely on the information in the tables, please first check these sources to ensure that the table data remains accurate. These tables are not an exhaustive list of all US domiciled ETFs that are HMRC reporting funds.
